CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The Brother from the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School called today in connection with the purchase of a pump necessary for filling the tank in hauling water to the school.

I understand a new truck is being supplied and the pump required is one mounted on the truck and operates from the truck motor. It is fast and saves a lot of hard labor. Fairbanks-Morse has one of these pumps and can supply it immediately. The cost, I understand, is approximately $100.00.

Brother informs me that the old pump is useless and one of the same type would cost at least $155.00. As stated above the pump is available now but may not be in a week's time. I would, therefore, recommend authority be granted for the purchase of the pump immediately.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa March 15 1947

Mr A G HAMILTON
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Winnipeg Manitoba

Charge Indian Affairs
Mines and Resources
Indian Affairs Branch,

OTTAWA.

Will you kindly refer to
Department letter 126-9-5 (W.T.I.) in
connection with the new truck being
supplied the Sandy Bay Indian Residential
School.

The Reverend Principal was in the
office today and advises that this truck
requires a 2,000 gallon tank. He claims
the one at the school is too small and that
if a new one was supplied there water worries
would be over.

Indian Agent.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Truck Water Tank for Sandy Bay School

Dear Sir:

The above school will be receiving any day this week the 3 ton Ford truck which your Department was kind enough to order. It will be delivered to them by the Ford Motor Company of Winnipeg.

The water tank which is required for the above must hold 1,000 gallons and cannot be bought ready-made. It must be of the gasoline type tanks, oval in shape and the length of the truck chassis.

There are several firms in the city of Winnipeg which make a specialty of the manufacturing of such tanks. I am listing a few so that you may know where to apply for this service.

1) Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works Ltd., Logan Ave.
2) Vulcan Iron Works Ltd., Sutherland and Maple.
3) Westeel Products Limited, CNR Tracks & Desautels.
4) Canadian Rogers Sheet, Metal & Roofing Ltd., 1109 Winnipeg Ave.

We are trying to have the truck held in Winnipeg by the Ford Motor Works so that it will be available to the Company which secures the contract for the building of the tank.

...2(over)
The school principal is very anxious that this job be completed as quickly as possible so as to avoid the high cost of water transportation which the Department is now daily assuming.

So we hope that your purchasing Department will proceed as expeditiously as it can.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

March 24, 1947.

PLEASE FURNISH THE FOLLOWING SUPPLIES FOR USE OF

Purpose for which required: Sandy Bay Residential School No. 584.

NOTE.—Requisition for non-consumable equipment, state if New Issue or Replacement.

Consumable equipment and supplies use columns 1 and 2.

| Quantity | Unit Price | TOTAL |
|----------|------------|-------|
|          |            |       |

1 - 1,000 gallon water tank.

This water tank is intended for the three ton Ford truck which was recently purchased for this school. The tank should be oval in shape and the length of the truck chassis. I am informed that the tank could be secured from one of the following firms in Winnipeg:

1. Manitoba Bridge & Iron Works, Ltd., Logan Ave.
2. Vulcan Iron Works Ltd., Sutherland and Maple.
3. Westeel Products Limited, CNH Tracks & Desautels.
4. Canadian Rogers Sheet, Metal & Roofing Ltd., 1109 Winnipeg Ave.

Water tank used on the former truck is actually too small. Consequently, with the larger truck it is advisable to supply a 1,000 gallon tank so as to avoid unnecessary labour.

I hereby certify that I have personal knowledge that all the above articles are required in the Department and for Departmental purposes only. The expenditure required by this requisition is strictly unavoidable and the public interest will suffer if it is not made.

Apr. 14th, 1947.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary,

Last July 11th you informed us by letter that an amount of $155.00 would be allowed by the department for the painting of the barn at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. To date no remittance has been received to cover the cost of this work done.

Yours truly,

J. Lambert, O.M.I.
Principal.
Ottawa, April 22nd, 1947.

Dear Father Lambert:

We have your letter of the 14th instant with reference to the amount of $155. that we promised to allow for labour for painting the barn at the Sandy Bay School.

The delay is due to the fact that we cannot find any record of having received receipted pay lists. If you forward these, immediate attention will be given to refunding the amount of $155.

Yours very truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. J. Lambert, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sandy Bay Indian Res. School,
Marius, Manitoba.

PP/MAD
PRATT MARINE & MANUFACTURING LTD.
290 Fort Street
WINNIPEG MANITOBA.

14 December 1946.

Dominion Government,
Mines & Resources Dept.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
538 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Gentlemen:

A good many months ago an individual unknown to us left a small CLARK pumping unit with us for repairs. He advised us that this unit belonged to the SANDY BAY INDIAN SCHOOL.

Would you be kind enough to advise this School that we are unable to obtain replacement parts for the unit and that we desire their directions re its disposition. There is a labour charge of $6.00 involved as the unit had to be completely disassembled in order to ascertain the cause and extent of the damage.

Yours very truly,

PRATT MARINE & MANUFACTURING LTD.
C.A. Pratt,
President.
Mr. J. Waite,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter received from the Pratt Marine & Manufacturing Company, 290 Fort Street and also copy of a letter just received from Father Lambert.

I wish you would discuss this with Father Lambert and, if possible, arrange for the return of the funds to the Sandy Bay School. Father Lambert in future should deal with your office in connection with matters of this nature. I am leaving the matter with you and as far as I am concerned the incident is closed.

Yours truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
for Manitoba.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, July 3rd, 1947.

Mr. S.J. Waite, Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

We have received your letters of May 28th and June 16th in connection with the request that you have received from the principal of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

In the current year's appropriation for the Sandy Bay school there was included an amount of $2,000. for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment. We have already either authorized or paid the following:

- New Tank $405.00
- Piping $725.00
- Labour painting $155.00
- Barn $470.00

In addition to the above, we have decided to place an order for the blower in order to permit the school management to use coal instead of wood in the future.

Careful consideration has been given to the renewed request of the principal for a new engine and generator. To purchase these would involve a considerable amount and as a result the funds specifically provided for this school in the current year's appropriation will be greatly exceeded. It is our intention to secure the following:

"1 only "Lister" 3 Cylinder, 4 Cycle, Tank cooled diesel engine rated at 27 H.P. at 1000 RPM at 330 feet altitude. The Bore and stroke 4½" x 5½",
"Flywheel - 26" x 4½"
Fuel Tank - 20 gallons
Water Tank - 450 gallons. Size 42" x 84"

"I only size C 14" 8 groove pulley $1,745.00

"The above price includes the 8 groove pulley and the usual equipment, exhaust silencer, air silencer, fuel tank and piping, starting handle, set of tools, fuel funnel with strainer, water tank and connections. The cylinder liner is treated with the Lister process of chrome hardening.

"I only Generator."

You should consult the principal and ascertain if he considers the equipment mentioned would meet his requirements. It is the same type of machine as we recently supplied to the Beauval Residential School. An immediate reply would be appreciated as it will probably require some time to secure this equipment.

In view of the expenditures outlined in this letter and the further equipment that the Department is prepared to purchase, you should point out to the principal very definitely that we will not be in a position to consider any further requests for the Sandy Bay Residential School during the current fiscal year.

We do not intend to authorize at the present time the expenditure requested for the installation of additional wash basins and for eaves trough.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir:

According to the suggestions made at the Conventions held at Lebret this month, there quite a number of changes to be made in the management of our schools.

We have been told that your Department will readily supply our needs with some kind of liquid soap special to the very hard water that we have here.

Thankfully yours,

W.T.
Soaps and Detergents for Schools, etc.

This is a project that I worked on for a long time hoping to get a formula and a water-chart that would be useful all over Canada. The project is still incomplete. The Bureau of Mines is still collecting the data on hardness of water in various areas.

Where a school wants advice in the meantime, the principal should write to one of the big soap companies in the Toronto area. They are very co-operative.

If it is liquid toilet soap for hand dispensers the principal should ask for the soap produced to Government specification 2-GP-1 with directions for use.

September 16, 1947.

The attached list of material was handed into the agency office on the 13th instant, by Father J. Lambert, Principal of Sendy Bay Residential School.

The material is required for making a partition in the grade 1 classroom. At present there are 115 children in attendance, and he advises that there will be 140 in attendance by the end of this week. He claims that he will have two Grade 1 pupils, "A" and "B" classes. The intention is to divide the classroom into two rooms for these classes, so there will be no interference. He claims to have teachers for each class. This class room is in addition to the usual junior and senior classrooms which will not be changed. The idea of the "A" and "B" classes is for backward pupils, or for children of ten to twelve years of age who are just starting school. They will be promoted to the usual junior room as soon as their progress warrants the change.

The list of material is complete, and will make a sound-proof wall. The work of erecting will be done by the school staff.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

We are experiencing trouble with Diesel motor of the lighting plant; one of the flywheels worked loose two or three times during the past year, and this week it was knocking so bad that we had to take it off. The motor cannot run very long in such a condition. In a letter received from the department last fall, we were notified that the motor would be replaced by a new one. To date nothing further has been done nor heard on this matter. The present motor has been running since 1938 and has been carrying a heavy overload since 1929 when the two wings were added to the school.

The heating and water systems are both powered by automatic electric motors drawing heavily on the new set of batteries installed last winter. These are giving good service, but they will not stand their guaranteed time even with the good care we are giving them, the motor being in such a poor condition. The present condition of the motor may bring on every serious emergency any time, and we are without authority to solve such an emergency should a breakdown occur. The batteries even in their A-1 shape could not carry the load for more than twelve hours. Last year, in June, a breakdown occurred and we were a full week without power. Luckily at that time of the year the load is at its lightest. We could not possibly encounter a like emergency in winter and carry on with the school work.

We wish to notify you beforehand of the present state of affairs and ask for instructions now in case a breakdown should occur and which we feel is bound to come about in a very short time. We suggest it would be preferable to install a 27 h.p. automatic lighting plant which would start when the heavy load comes on and save the batteries from carrying the overload.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

(Rev.) Fr. J. Lambert, O.M.I.
Principal.

February 3, 1948.

Dear Father Plourde:

We are in receipt of your letter of January 29th with reference to the equipment which the dietitian recommended be supplied to the Sandy Bay Residential School.

As you are aware, the list included in your letter includes equipment that we have not been supplying to residential schools.

At the present time funds are not available. However, we will be prepared to reconsider your request after April 1st but I am not in a position at the present time to give any definite promise that the articles will be supplied.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,

Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa, Ontario.

OTTAWA.

Re: Dietitian's Report on
Sandy Bay Indian School
October 8 and 9, 1947.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

I wish to draw your attention to the recommendation of the dietitian for the improvement of the kitchen facilities of the above school.

1. Proper dishwashing, pot washing facilities, also for washing dairy utensils.

2. Rearrangement of stove and cook's tables in the kitchen for better work.

3. The installation of proper cupboard in the kitchen for storage of current food supply, utensils and cleaning materials.

4. Installation of a walk-in refrigerator.

5. Meat grinder.

6. Electric mixer.

7. Potato peeler.

8. The installation of a fan and hood over the kitchen stove.

As the above are urgently advised by your dietitian, it is to be hoped that you will provide them at an early date.

Yours very truly,

J.-O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Sandy Bay Indian School,
Marius, P.O., Man.,
Jan. 28, 1948.

Yours truly,

J. Lambert, O.M.I.

Ottawa, February 14, 1948.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Sandy Bay Indian Residential School,
Province of Manitoba.

We have a request for a new electric plant at this school. At the present time they are using the following:

One 6 K.W. Lister diesel-driven generating unit - this was purchased at a cost of $1,450 in December, 1938.

A new set of Globelite batteries, 450 A.H., 110 volt, was supplied in December, 1946.

Since the original lighting plant was installed, the accommodation in the building has increased and also the number of pupils enrolled. As a consequence, we are advised that the following motors are in use:

1 ½ H.P. for washing machine.
1 ½ H.P. for water system in the stable.
1 ½ H.P. for grinder in the workshop.
1 2 H.P. for saw, compressor and drill.
1 ½ H.P. for cream separator.
1 ½ H.P. for heating system.
1 ½ H.P. for water system.
1 ½ amp. for DC to AC convertor.

In addition to the above, there are approximately three hundred electric lights with an average of approximately 60 watts each.
It has been suggested by the management of the school that an 8 K.W., 16 H.P. diesel would take care of the load and provide sufficient reserve power in case of necessity.

I would appreciate it if you would let me have your opinion on the matter in order that we may arrange with the Purchasing Branch for the securing of the equipment required.

PP/MGD

Director.
Sandy Bay Indian School.
Marius P.O. Man. Feb. 6, 1948

With reference to Mr. Hoey's memorandum dated April 27th in connection with the above and bearing your marginal notation thereon of the 29th, we would refer you to our memorandum of March 2nd in which we suggest that the Indian Affairs Branch defer action in ordering lighting plant equipment until such time as an Officer from this Division could carry out an electrical inspection.

We feel that it would be more satisfactory to have an Officer from this Division inspect the existing electrical system and make recommendations than to ask Mr. Gow in Winnipeg to assign a member of his staff to make a technical survey and report his findings upon which this Division would make recommendations for lighting plant equipment.

We understand that the Indian Affairs Branch has a plan under consideration whereby an inspection company would conduct surveys and prepare reports and recommendations in connection with the structures and services at a number of schools including the above.

**COMMON ORIGIN**

Anthropology studies Man in all his aspects, including his curiosity about himself. Anthropology, which gives Man a much better understanding of his physical characteristics.

A famous study at present seems to be the Dr. E. H. Evans of Chicago University, who is trying to determine where Eskimos came from. His conclusion is that Eskimos are practically identical with Europeans, and therefore they are not descendants of European race populations, but immigrants from Siberia. They are probably the oldest people north and developed their peculiarities early.

Dr. Evans' theory is supported by the fact that many ancient relics have been reported as far south as Labrador Island.

**NEW DRUG TO FIGHT T.B.**

CHICAGO — A new synthetic drug for the treatment of tuberculosis has been developed. This drug has not yet been tried in experiments on humans. However, the drug was reported to have had an extremely significant effect against the spread of tuberculosis among animals.

It also has the qualities needed to combat the growth of the bacillus, which is protected by a layer of wax. It attacks the living portion of the bacillus cell. During the course of the experiment, the living cell of the bacillus, such as lactic acid and streptomycin, are relatively insoluble in fat.

**ST. BONIFACE MEETING**

ST. BONIFACE, Man. — The second annual meeting of the Provincial Council of the Oblate Fathers in Canada, convened at St. Boniface for a three day study of problems concerning the welfare and training of the Indians of Canada. The council, consisting of several missionaries, many day-schools, and hundreds of mission posts under the care of the Oblate Missionaries across Canada, discussed the problems presented over the convention. A review of the work done by the Oblate Fathers and Welfare training Commission for the past twelve years was presented, and the council discussed the future plans for the advancement of education, cooperative, recreational centers on the reservations, and the formation of a Welfare Association for the Indians of the Manitou Oblate Province.

Rev. O.M.I., and the Rev. J. O. Plozure, O.M.I., were re-elected to their posts by acclamation. Very Rev. A. Jordan, O.M.I., of Prince-Rupert, B.C., was elected Vice-President.

**HEADS MISSIONS**

Very Rev. Fr. Ph. Scheffer, O.M.I., Provincial of the Manitoba Province took office at St. Boniface May 1.

**VISITS SANDY BAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL**

SANDY BAY, Man. — Sometimes ago I had the occasion of visiting an Indian Residential School. I had often heard of Indian Schools from different people on various occasions. The impression received from these had been so developed in me as to desire to find out for myself just what was being done in Indian Schools. It was not without interest therefore that I took advantage of an offer extended to visit an Indian Technical School. I say Technical on account of the training received.

Sandy Bay Indian School is Father Beaulieu, pastor of the Reserve, and to Father Florentin, Saulteaux, Father Jean-Baptiste, Eab-and-Flow, Crane River and other reserve posts, was also sent Father Chagnon, who spent most of his life as principal of the school. Father Chagnon has, as a hobby, collected one of the most complete collections of birds' nests in Canada. These birds are housed in glass cases, as a permanent exhibit. Mr. O. Brayer and V. Laviole, devote their time to the upkeep of the school and the supervision of training to the pupils.

Indian Land Title in Canada

In view of the paramount importance given to the land estates of the Indians called 'Reserves', it seems opportune for your Parliamentarian Observers to publish a few historical facts on this subject.

The British Government has always recognized the Indian's title to land, which consisted of the whole area of the country, the districts occupied by them, and the Crown reserved to itself the exclusive right to treat with the Indians. In the case of Quebec, on the other hand, during the days of French Rule in Canada, the French claimed the new colony by right of discovery, and did not recognize any Indian title. As a matter of grace the French did not set apart reserves for the Indians, but applied the same exceptions to the reserve in Quebec and in the Maritimes.

The British assumed the French title to lands after the conquest, and the Indians were confirmed in the possession of the reserves which occurred by the Proclamation of 1763. However, in British Columbia the Provincial Government has not recognized any Indian title, and the Dominion Government has set apart reserves in which the Government retains an interest, called reverorsions, which will be held until such time as the Indians shall cease to require the land.

In Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, where the provinces have taken over the old policy of recognizing the Indian title has been followed. Large tracts of land have been ceded by the Indians to the Crown, and the proceeds are paid in goods or money, or for an annuity, or for both. In these Treaties the Indians reserved certain areas of land, which are now held by the Crown in the Crown, in trust for the Indians, and the ceded territory is administered by the province. At times Indians surrender their title for the purpose of clearing the land for themselves, and the proceeds are placed to the credit of the band.

We may add that during the period of military control in Canada (1763 to 1841), the Indians were treated more or less as independent sovereigns. However, the attitude of Canada was influenced to a marked degree by defeats on the one hand, to win the support of the Indians as friends of the Crown, and on the other, through fears of Indian attacks on his frontier settlements.

The following period, (1841-1867) is marked by a gradual change from a policy which was dictated by consideration of fear and defense, to one which directed efforts to educate, civilize and christianize the Indian. The British North America Act transferred the authority of the Indian Affairs Federal Government to the provinces. It was easy; in 1868 a Dominion Act which consolidated previous acts and summed up the best features of Indian legislation was passed by the federal government. There was no education and development of the former policy, elastic enough to accommodate the problems of the various Indian groups in the country.

The "closed reserve" policy has been enforced since the days of the Proclamation of 1763; the maintenance of the reserve intact has been, indeed, the basic principle of the Indian administration, and of incalculable benefit to the Indians.

Catholic Welfare Associations

Among recent organisations for Indian welfare our readers are familiar with the Catholic Indian Institute of B.C., which is under the direction of Chief Bishop and other leading Indians who carry out social work on their home reserves.

The work of this Institute is distinctly that of a Catholic Social Action organisation, taking part in all the activities of human life. It is religious, intellectual, educational, charitable, economic and social, seeking to work towards the spread of religious influences in the home and community. In existence for four years, the Catholic Institute of B.C. has undertaken the training of the Indians for each mission, thereby laying a solid foundation for moral and spiritual welfare as well as for thorough social development according to the spirit of the Church.

A much older and time-proven organisation, essentially a religiously religious in its purpose for the training of lay leaders among the Indians, is the parishes of St. Joseph's and St. Mary's, instituted for the Sioux in the Dakotas and Montana, over 40 years ago, by the late Apostle of the Sioux, Bishop Henry. Upon the Bishop's advice, Father Jerome Hunt, O.S.B., founded those Societies at St. Michael Mission, North Dakota, in 1886. At first under the direction of the priests, and later on their own account, the groups studied and discussed the truths of the Catholic religion and their application to practical life. They hold every Sunday afternoon, interspersed with hymns and prayers.

These Societies met with extraordinary success on the Sioux reservations, and the Indians responded to them in a way which would have been impossible for the missionaries to do alone. The Societies hold local congresses every two years, each time at a different mission, and general congresses, which delegates come from the various States.

The first congress was held at Standing Rock Reservation, N.D., in 1891, and several congresses have been held every year ever since.

It has been the privilege of your editor to witness, as guest missionary, several of these Congresses in the Dakotas and in Montana. Preparation for a congress and its management is the responsibility of the Local Committees. Committees are formed, delegates are elected from various missions and collections are made for their expenses.

The object of the congress is to bring together a large bower is erected for the meeting near the mission chapel. The sessions are conducted by the Indians; a different chairman is chosen for each session and the discussions are conducted with gravity and strict adherence to the rules.

The speakers, men and women, deliver addresses generally on some religious topic, such as the Christian Family. The meetings and religious services at which missionaries preach in the native tongue, last three days.

At the close of the congress a community banquet is served, in which all have contributed. Communion closes with a solemn procession, the men and women in full regalia, carrying their banners, sashes and other insignia according to their rank and office.

The absence of amusements of any kind, the strict order and discipline observed during the congress, the zeal shown by the leaders in seeking out the laikends, and the promptness to receive the Sacraments, are very striking indeed. At the close of the congress, the Indians return home with new ideals, and the subjects discussed at the attention of the congress will be discussed in the Sunday meetings again and again.

The foundation of an Indian Welfare Association with a religious as well as a social program of action has been laid down in the Oblate Missions of the Saskatchewan Province, and will include North Western Ontario and Saskatchewan. It is hoped that it will meet with the full cooperation of the eight thousand Catholic Indians in this mission territory, and that it will foster to a high degree the social, economic and cultural progress of the Indians.

G. L.

The other departments in the school are on the east end of the building. St. Joseph's Church is on the north, P.Q., who are very devoted to the church. The kitchen, infirmary, sewing room and bakery are under the care, and they make the meals and do the work-keeping. Many beautiful pieces of fan- tasy work of woven material were shown to me.

The lay staff comprises Eddie Leduc, principal; E. Leduc, athletic coach; E. Leducotte and N. Trudeau, farm and dairy instructors; and M. Dufault, night-watchman.

Visiting the four classrooms, with their desks and chairs, struck me by the neatness with which everything is arranged. The school curriculum is the same that at its provincial schools, save teaching in English.

The infirmary is well stocked with medicine, and it has two medical wards for the patients. The pupils enjoy weekly educational as well as recreational shows.

Having completed the visit of the buildings I went into the main buildings: the modern dairy stable; the chicken-coop, where 3,700 eggs are gathered monthly; the workshop, well equipped with tools for the training of the senior boys.

Then I went to meet the Field-nurse, Miss Marie Cartier, R.N., who cooperates with Mr. Raymond Marie, also a R.N., in the health care of the school pupils and of the Indians. Since last year, the mortality rate has been greatly reduced at Sandy Bay, and the health of the Indians improved.

My last call was made at the mailing-post of Nap. Roy, near the school. The Marius Post-Office is located at this post. Mr. Marius is very co-operative with the school staff, and his services are appreciated by all.

The accompanying pictures, on pages 2 and 8, will tell a better story than I can explain by words. I am glad to state that what struck me most in my visit was that perfect cooperation between the Oblate Fathers and the Indian Affairs Branch, as well as between the Indian Affairs Service division and the Department of National Health, can be worked for the greater advantage of the Indian population, not only here at Sandy Bay, but in scores of other educational centres for the Indians across Canada.

The story is now: Daniel Little (Hanpa), grandson of the Sun-Dreamed, brought up in a Government Indian school, returns to Wood Mountain quite bewildered by his experiences. His grand-father wants him to marry the Doc-Maiden's daughter, a woman and end of a white man. At the death of his grandfather Daniel showed his true feelings by killing the white man who had tried to kill his horse, with his friend, Toto, and went to Poplar, Montana, to seek his fortune.

Daniel and Toto work at the Ramsay ranch for a few days. Daniel is paid $2,000 by the owner, Mr. Ramsay, but he is not satisfied. Meanwhile he inherits $2,000 from his grandfather; and he decides to return to Wood Mountain and seek his fortune. He goes there in order to set himself up on a small farm, before going back to Poplar, Montana.

As the two friends arrive home, Pauline is heartbroken. Upon his arrival at Wood Mountain a casual remark causes Daniel to realize that Pauline is engaged to another man, Doc-Maiden, whom he has blindly ignored until now.

The annual Rodeo at Wood Mountain is an event which attracts visitors from distant points in South Dakota and Montana. The early frosts have been received, and the spirit of the old West is being awakened after a few days of rain. A huge tent is pitched in the valley of the Wood Mountain, where visitors are housed by tents; dining rooms are erected; and a vast dancing platform is set up under the stars. Visitors wander about, enjoying the rodeo-grounds, swings, show-tents, and amusement stands.

Rodeo and dude riders and cowgirls circulate in their gaudy apparel; old Indians in full regalia, engaged in watching a rodeo or eating a parade meal; morning and afternoon races of ponies, riders undismounted, bucking wagons, bull-riding, drag races, and a huge crowd. But the largest event which gains attention each year is the bronc-busting event, one of the most essential features of the rodeo.

From the top of the surrounding hills, the view of the large encampment is thrilling indeed. In the valley, surrounded by populous hills, the sun's rays weave its way through the trees. The prairie presents the peculiar beauty of the valley like sentinels, adding their perennial beauty to the scene.

The Indian camp was set up on a little elevation to the west of the arena. There Dan and Toto had set their canvas tents, low and squatting among the towering trees. The Indians, ponies, hobbled, grazed close by. As the sun rose upon the opening of the rodeo, preparations were made at the arena, and by early afternoon, a huge crowd gathered to witness the opening of the rodeo.

Daniel and Toto mounted their ponies, and took part in the colorful parade along the rodeo track, which marked the opening of the rodeo, while a Montana High School Band played martial tunes. As the riders were recognized by their friends, much hand-shaking and cheering was made as the riders waved their sombreros.

Daniel was keeping his eyes eagerly on the solid row of cars which surrounded the race-track, when near the finish chute, he greeted loudly by the high-pitched voice of LeBeque. Daniel looked up, smiling, and shouted: "Hi, partner, in beckoning! LeBeque was alone.

The parade over, Daniel, booked to ride in the very first race, proceeded to the corral chutes. The events succeeded one another in rapid succession: the slow riding, calf-roping, bronco-busting, wild-cow milking; by mid-afternoon a race was being scheduled for Daniel, when LeBeque rushed to the chute.

"Kola," answered Daniel, "I have reasons of my own. I am seeking some one, perhaps."

"Say, partner," retorted Toto, "I'm fed up with this business. You're No-Man's Horse. Come and see your friend LeBeque. He has invited me to come and see him".

"A good idea," said Toto, "and man, happen to find an occasion to meet the Doc-Maiden, without having to go out of your way yourself."

"Yes, I do," replied Marianne, quivering. Toto cast a questioning glance toward Daniel, who asked:

"Do you wish that I stay out of this?" — "No, if you promise to keep away about it, I do not mind."

"Well," said Toto, refreshing himself once more from his flask, "my name is Toto, and I am man now, I am pleased you call me your uncle. I will tell you something which will make you teach you a great lesson. When I was eighteen I went to Haskell Institute, and I came back there with honors. I went to work as a hog-keeper in a ranch, and I did well. I became engaged to a white woman, Dallas, whom I trusted completely. We bought a house and a car. We trusted another, had few friends, and our two children together were like heaven. We had a child, but we lost her after she was born. She was secluded, and I believed we could have lived on like that. One day, late, however, we had gone to a dance. Dallas was a perfect dancer—when I noticed her, I thought I would seek her. A friend of mine told me she had gone out. I followed her, and I saw her in the shadows below the balcony, with my wife in the arms of a strange man. When I saw and knew, I rushed to my car and fled to Minnesota. There I cashed in my chances for half a dollar, turned over the balance and the deed on the house to Dallas, and left her. Dallas married and divorced a divorcee from Dallas, and left the world I had lived in, and which had destroyed my happiness. Now I have found peace and contentment, as a wanderer among the white people, here in Wood Mountain.

Marianne was wiping her eyes. Toto continued: "And this is, Marianne, what I want you to happen for me. It is really up to you now. Hanpa's trail is open to you. You must be there waiting for him".

"They what about the white woman Dallas? Is it true, sobbed Marianne? "She ran away from me last month?"

"I don't know," replied Toto, "but I can say new is that my kola is at the crossroads". (To be continued)

DAKOTAS IN SPORTSMEN SHOW

One of the more entertaining features of this year's Manitoba Sportsmen's Show is the Canoe-Tilting Contest, featuring a pair of full-blooded Dakota Indians opposing a French-Canadian timberrman from the woods of Northern Ontario. This contest is even a more popular feature at some of the leading shows. It offers a spectacular display with thrills, spills and a goodly amount of humor.

The Dakota Indian pair, further featured in the program, demonstrated their repertoire of bird and wild animal calls.

Dakota Indians Ed Muckle and Tom Sanderson give a ducking to Ernie Simpson and Joe Perron, Northern Ontario guides, in the contest held at the Winnipeg Sportsmen Show, proving the redmen are still masters of the canoe. The contest was held May 11.

GENERAL:

We have figured on the supply of Insulation Material, Moisture Vapor Material, Asphalt Emulsion Cement, and also the supply and complete installation of Frigidaire Refrigerating Equipment, suitable to maintain zero degree temperatures in a Low Temperature Storage Freezer, with interior measurements 8'9" x 5' x 9' high, and the Cooler Room capable of maintaining 36° to be built adjacent to the low temperature room, with inside measurements 10' x 6' x 9' high.

A blueprint showing the proposed layout of the two rooms is attached hereto.

INSULATION, Etc.

For the Zero Degree Room, we will supply 2,590 pounds of Redwood Bark Wool Insulation Material, together with 4 rolls of Neponset Asphalt Emulsion Moisture Vapor Barrier Paper, 2 rolls of Anchor Paper and 2 gallons of Bracco Asphalt Emulsion Cement.

For the 36° Cooler Room, we will supply 498 pounds of Redwood Bark Wool Insulation Material, 1 roll of Neponset Asphalt Emulsion Paper and 1 roll of Anchor Paper and 1 gallon of Bracco Asphalt Emulsion Cement.

We will also supply one #5 Standard Cold Storage Door for the Low Temperature Room and one #1 Cold Storage Door for the 36° Cooler Room. Both of these cold storage doors come complete with frames and cold storage door hardware.

COOLING UNITS FOR THE LOW TEMPERATURE ROOM:

We will supply and install 12 only 7" Frigidaire Eutectic Plates with minus 6° Eutectic Solution. The Eutectic Solution fills completely the plates and has holdover capacity to enable equipment to operate and provide proper temperatures with a running time depending upon the outside weather conditions, varying from three to five hours each morning and from three to five hours each evening. In other words, the installation of this equipment is designed in such a fashion that the 110 Volt D.C. Current supply need not necessarily operate 24 hours per day.

COOLING UNITS FOR THE 36° COOLER ROOM:

We will supply and install 7 only 9" Frigidaire Eutectic Plates with plus 18° Eutectic Solution. These plates are figured with the correct solution to balance out so that the running time of the refrigerating machinery will provide proper temperatures in the cooler room when the refrigeration compressor is operated the same length of time concurrently with the time it will require to be operated to cool down the low temperature room.
CONDENSING UNITS:

We will supply and install one Model AF-6200 Frigidaire Freon Air Cooled Condensing Unit, equipped with 110 Volt D.C. Motor, 2 H.P.

This condensing unit has ample capacity to provide proper conditions of temperature even in the hottest weather. It will require to operate from three to five hours in the morning and from three to five hours in the evening. An automatic control will be provided and included in the installation which will automatically shut off the 110 Volt D.C. Electric Motor when the temperature in each of the two rooms reaches the desired point. It will be necessary for those persons operating the equipment to start the condensing unit each morning and then again each evening. Experience after using the equipment, will indicate to the persons operating the equipment just at which time the condensing unit should be started.

This equipment will include in the installation a Frigidaire Accumulator Interchanger which will increase the efficiency of the total installation by approximately 5%.

GUARANTEE:

Frigidaire equipment carries with it a complete guarantee against defective parts and improper workmanship for a period of one year from the date the equipment is placed in operation. More important to you, however, as a user is the fact that genuine Frigidaire equipment continues to deliver satisfactory service year in and year out for many years after any guarantee has expired.

PRICE:

Cost of the above complete installation, including all necessary insulating material, cold storage doors, and refrigeration equipment installed complete with all necessary installation labor, parts, Freon refrigerant, Frigidaire oil, and in fact everything necessary to make this a completely operating job, with the exception of the lumber and labor necessary to build the two coolers and install the insulating material, etc., is $2,620.00. This price would be subject to your discount of 10%.

Not included in this price is the cost of electric wiring necessary to connect the electric motor, switches, etc. to the electrical services in the building.
We sincerely trust that the above will be of interest to you and that we may be favored with your valued order.

SPECIFICATIONS

Frigidaire Flowing Cold Condensing Units

Air Cooled Models F6H, F6J — Water Cooled Models FW6H, FW6J

Frigidaire Condensing Units are available in a range of sizes to meet every Commercial Refrigeration need. Features listed below combine to produce maximum refrigeration capacity at a minimum operating cost.

**Compressor**—Two cylinder, slow speed, vertical, single acting, reciprocating type.

**Service Valves**—Two-way type with outlet provided for gauge connection. Large forged brass discharge valve is employed. Malleable iron suction valve has connection for 1½" tubing.

**Lubrication**—Adequate lubrication for all moving parts is supplied by oil splash. Large oil wells on top of main bearings supply oil continuously to the bearings.

**Drive**—Three pulley coupling system provides positive and efficient drive. Flywheel, composed of high strength case iron, is statically balanced. Flywheel, pulley, and belts are guarded by a heavy metal screen.

**Automatic Belt Adjustment**—Prevents slippage, and assures proper belt tension at all times for efficient power transmission.

**Motors**—Specially designed for refrigeration duty. Capable of starting several times their rated horsepower. For standard equipment, 110/220 volt, single phase, 60 cycle, A.C., repulsion-induction type motors are employed. Motors of other electrical characteristics are available on special order. A.C. motors mounted on rubber feet assure operation.

**Automatic Control**—Quick acting pressure switch operated from the low pressure side of the system. A high pressure control stops condensing unit if pressures become excessive. Contactors are furnished for either A.C. or D.C. motors and incorporate thermal overload protection with automatic reset.

**Condensing Unit Base**—Sturdy, reinforced case iron.

**Finish**—Entire unit finished in black baked enamel.

**Refrigerant**—Charged with 8 pounds of Freon-12, the safe refrigerant developed by Frigidaire and General Motors.

**Frigilube Oil**—Charged with 3 pounds of special 150 viscosity oil, refined to Frigidaire specifications.

**Safety Approval**—Listed by Underwriters Laboratories.

WATER COOLED MODELS

"Econoflow" Water Cooled Condenser—Horizontal, steel shell type with internal finned water coil condensing surface. Economical and effective heat removal. Equipped with fusible plug, liquid level indicator, special liquid filter and liquid valve.

**Automatic Water Valve**—Operated from high pressure side of the system for economical water usage. Automatically regulates flow of water through condenser, thus compensating for variations in the refrigeration load and water temperatures.

COMPRESSOR BODY

1. **Valve-Head Design**—Eliminates oil pumping difficulties. Increases efficiency of compressor and assures quiet operation.

2. **Intake and Discharge Valves**—Use of precision Swedish spring steel assures quick acting and positive seating. Large valve areas in special cast cases and valve plate allow maximum efficiency.

3. **Cylinder Block and Cylinder Head**—Body of heavy nickel cast iron assures perfect alignment of moving parts. Cylinders accurately ground and honed to mirror-like smoothness. Bore 2¾", stroke 1¾". Sight glass in crankcase for checking oil level.

4. **Connecting Rod**—Drop-forged steel. I-beam construction. Centrifugal cast babbit bearing. Drilled for splint lubrication.

5. **Main Bearings**—Self-lubricating type with pressure bearing forced against a hardened, highly polished rotating steel surface. Flooded with oil to assure positive sealing with minimum friction losses.

6. **Cylinder Head**—Dome type for balanced performance. High grade cast iron.

7. **Cylinder Head Pistons**—Special alloy cast iron. Precision fit to cylinders. Equipped with compression rings and oil grooves. Full-floating pistons assure smooth running.

8. **Pistons**—Drop-forged, tough Soltite steel. Extra large, ground and polished main bearing surfaces.

9. **Main Bearings**—Self lubricating, filled with oil impregnated bronze bearings.

10. **Bearing Strainer**—Fine mesh monel metal screen in suction cavity acts as a scale trap. Small orifice in cavity returns oil to crankcase.

Authority is hereby requested for the purchase of one Snow Plow, for the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. The road from the Residential School to highway #5 is six miles in length; this also fills up, and as this road is used by the school, and the reserve, also our Farm Instructor, days are lost until this road is opened up again by the Principal of the above school.

Under the circumstances I would recommend this request for the above mentioned snow plow.

Attached please find letter supplied by the Father Principal, of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School for your consideration.

MEMORANDUM:

COL. H. F. NEARY.

I am attaching hereto copy of a letter dated the 17th instant, addressed to the Purchasing Agent of this Department, regarding certain accounts which are outstanding with the Winnipeg office of Crane Limited.

I am writing the Winnipeg office of Crane Limited in connection with all of the accounts which were forwarded here, with the exception of two. The papers regarding these are attached hereto. You will see that I have noted in pencil that one of the accounts refers to the Fort Alexander School and the other to the Sandy Bay School. I have gone over your files regarding these two schools and have turned down some papers which have reference to the items mentioned. I have also been in touch with the office of the Purchasing Agent. He informs me that Purchase Order No. 19377 was issued on May 16th, 1947, in favour of Crane Limited. It referred to certain pipe, elbows, etc., required by the Sandy Bay School. He also informs me that this order was given to the Company F.O.B. Amaranth. The second Purchase Order No. 20930, or No. 30930, was issued on the 25th of June, 1948, for the Fort Alexander School. The order was F.O.B. Pine Falls.

Although I have not been able to get full information, my opinion is that these orders were issued in favour of the Company and that part of the orders was sent almost immediately and, in accordance with the tender, the freight was paid by the Company. Later on they completed the order, but, in both cases, it was overlooked that the material was to go F.O.B. the nearest town in each case. I presume this is the reason why they are now making claim for freight on these two shipments.

I am replying to the letter received, and informing the Company that they will hear further from you regarding the two accounts dealt with in this memorandum.

General Executive Assistant.

The Director,
Indian Health Services,
Department of National Health & Welfare,
Ottawa.

Attention Dr. W.L. Falconer

Re: Typhoid Fever - Sandy Bay Reserve

On March 5th two children from this reserve were admitted to Portage Hospital with typhoid fever. One (Glen Flatfoot, age 8) was from the residential school and one (Frank Flatfoot, age 11) from his home. On March 12th two other boys from the school were also admitted to hospital but so far reports from the laboratory are negative.

Miss MacCarthy, R.N., was brought down from Morway House Hospital and on March 16th started immunization of all on the reserve and at school. No new cases have developed.

This reserve has had nineteen cases of typhoid since 1937 as follows:

| Year | Cases |
|------|-------|
| 1937 | 3     |
| 1939 | 2     |
| 1942 | 2     |
| 1945 | 2     |
| 1944 | 1     |
| 1945 | 7     |
| 1948 | 1     |

At least three of the above were at school on the reserve when they took sick. Most of the children at school go home at week-ends.

Inoculation with typhoid vaccine has been done at intervals in the past and may have prevented more widespread infection.

It is essential that pure water be provided. This is difficult .......
difficult in the Indians' homes but can be done at once in the school. I consider it absolutely essential that an automatic chlorinator be purchased and installed at the school at once. At present they were instructed to chlorinate by addition of chloride of lime to the tanks. During the winter this was not done.

Wallace and Tierman have a small automatic chlorinator of the type marked on the attached pamphlet. The cost is as follows:

- Chlorinator - $375.00
- 15 gal. crock - $12.00
- 100 lbs. HTH - $1.00
- Testing outfit - $22.00

Total - $440.00

The water for the Residential School is hauled by tank from the lake and dumped in tanks at the school.

Indians at home use either snow or haul water from the lake. They have been instructed to boil water.

Would you please consider this urgent.

W. J. Wood, M.D.,
Regional Superintendent,
Indian Health Services.

Dauphin,
Man.

Dear Mr. Gowans,

We wish to bring to the attention of the Department once again the different problems which still remain after several years. May we ask your cooperation in presenting them again to the Department for the new fiscal year.

Our main problems are water, electric power and roads. Hauling water from the lake by truck and tank presents a major problem in winter when blizzards and snow block the road. To remedy this situation we suggest building the present road higher and request the necessary machinery to maintain it. As you probably know, the railroad has favored us with a siding directly west of the
school. A good road to this point and the main highway, for the use of the school, nurse station, and reserve, is requested.

Our electric power needs are constantly increasing and the present overloaded old Diesel plant can not supply all the needed power.

This last winter we were very unfortunate in having to dispose of practically all our herd of cattle, because of Bang's disease. We ask for a special grant to help in securing another milk herd sufficient for the school needs.

A new shop is needed for the vocational training of the pupils. The present shop is not fit for use nor remodelling.

A special fence around the dug-out reservoir, a fence in front of school, eaves troughs for the school, fire escapes, water softener for the laundry, a new bake oven for the bakery, all items which are still to be furnished.

A walk-in refrigerator is an essential necessity for an institution as the school.

Miss McCready asked that the school kitchen and dining hall be modernised. A potato peeler, a food mixer and food chopper are items needed in the kitchen. An adding machine for the principal's office is also needed.

We also request a special grant for a hall for the social activities of the reserve as a whole and a follow-up
program to continue and bring into adult life the formation and instruction received in school.

We hope that you will be able to secure the favourable consideration of the department for these problems and needed items.

Yours truly,

J. Lambert, O.M.I.
Principal

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the power plant at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, in the Province of Manitoba, is practically worn out and will have to be replaced in the very near future;

THAT it is considered desirable to install electricity in this school;

THAT the Manitoba Power Commission has men at present working in the vicinity of the school and is prepared to connect this school with its line which would run from Amaranth, Manitoba;

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that the offer of the Manitoba Power Commission to install this line at a cost of Five Thousand One Hundred Dollars ($5,100.00) be accepted.

Dear Mr. Neary:

The Indian Residential School of Sandy Bay is still hauling water by truck a distance of three miles to supply the school for all purposes except that of watering the cattle. For this service, you have supplied a truck and have contributed $100.00 towards the running expenses and the payment of wages to the driver.

Winter conditions in Manitoba when at times the temperature goes down to 40, make the hauling of water for this school a difficult problem. Now that conditions are somewhat normal, we believe that money should be voted in the next estimates for installing a regular water system for this school, which will give a more abundant and sure supply of water.

Your engineer some ten years ago made a survey of this water project which might be used now for the purpose of securing prices from interested contractors. You know that a considerable amount of money was spent on that school some ten years ago and that it is now one of your best institutions. With a proper and regular water supply the School would be completely equipped.

Hoping that you will look into this matter as soon as possible, I remain,

Yours very truly,

REPORT ON
WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM
FOR
SANDY BAY INDIAN SCHOOL

Winnipeg, Manitoba.
September 5, 1934.

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
INTRODUCTORY:

In response to the request of the Department of Indian Affairs as contained in your letter of August 16th, Mr. J. T. Rose of this office and the writer visited Sandy Bay Indian School, spending August 23, 24 and 25th in making studies on the ground. A survey was made of what was considered the most practical route for a pipe line from Lake Manitoba to the school. This survey consisted of running a chained traverse by transit, running of precise levels to procure a ground profile, the taking of soundings off shore to ascertain intake conditions, the securing of borings along the traverse line, the location of buildings and the securing of elevations in the vicinity of the school buildings. An examination was made of the water supply that in addition to the installation of the school and data were collected relative to the water requirements of the Institution. A sample of water was taken from Lake Manitoba for analysis.

PRESENT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM:

The existing water supply at the Institution is briefly as follows: The school building is approximately 100' x 40' and rainfall upon the roof is collected into an underground cistern 12 feet in diameter and 10 feet deep, with a capacity of about 7,000 gallons. This cistern is in close proximity to the kitchen and the water is delivered to the kitchen by means of a hand pump located in the kitchen. This water is used for drinking, cooking and laundry purposes. For sanitary purposes three tanks with a combined capacity of 2,200 gallons are located in the attic of the building and a gravity water furnished the school. The water supply to these tanks comes from two sources, but the quality of the water is much the same. A comparatively deep well, approximately 250 feet from the school, is operated by a wind mill and a feed pipe leads...
to the water tanks, the energy necessary also being supplied by the windmill. A comparatively shallow well is located quite close to the workshop of the school and is connected to an underground cistern nearby; the dimensions of this cistern being about four feet square and sixteen feet deep. A pump driven by a small gasoline engine located in the workshop connects with this cistern and also to the storage tank in the attic and is operated during such periods as continued lack of sufficient wind to operate the windmill results in failure of water supply from the deeper well.

The Principal of the School stated that this shallow well appeared to be going dry. The water from both these wells is very hard and distinctly salty. It is unfit for drinking, cooking and laundry purposes in the school, but I understand that in addition to sanitary purposes it is also used in the steam heating system, high pressure boiler and domestic water heater.

The amount of water that can be collected into the soft water cistern from the roof, even in a year of average precipitation, is far from sufficient to meet the requirements of the very limited use to which this supply is put and consequently water has to be hauled from Lake Manitoba - two and one-third miles distant. The hauling is done by team and a 400-gallon metal tank mounted on a wagon is used. It appears that only an average of one tank per week is hauled from the lake.

The main school building is the only building equipped with a water supply system. Piping for both cold and hot water is installed and fire hose is in place on each floor. The hot water supply consists of a 300-gallon tank connected to the heating system boiler only, with the result that there is no hot water supply when the heating system is not in operation. There is no hot water supply boiler.
installed and also no high pressure steam boiler, and this latter unit is rather essential in an Indian School. Piping in the school is in poor condition.

WATER SUPPLY REQUIREMENTS:

We have been asked to report on the complete installation of an adequate water supply system for this school. Accordingly, for the purposes of this report we consider an adequate water supply system should include the following:

(1) A dependable source of water supply.
(2) A water supply safe for drinking, palatable, and not unreasonably hard.
(3) Continuous hot and cold water in the main school building, necessitating the installation of a new hot water supply boiler.
(4) A high pressure steam supply, necessitating the installation of a high pressure steam boiler.
(5) A water supply for stock, necessitating pipe connection to barn and installation of water supply for cattle and horses, also a separate pipe connection to hog pen to provide water supply during non-freezing period of year.
(6) A reasonable measure of fire protection.

SOURCE OF WATER SUPPLY:

To fulfill requirements (1) and (2) above, it is considered necessary to use Lake Manitoba as the source of water supply. Wells in the district around Sandy Bay School produce a salty water if driven to depth and shallow wells are not at all dependable.

A copy of the analysis of Lake Manitoba water accompanies this report. It shows the water to be hard and to contain a high amount of sodium chloride. However, it is considered that this water can be utilized without the use of filter, softener or chlorinator systems, even were it possible to install such systems. I would like to point out that this
analysis shows that trouble from incrusting solids must be anticipated in connection with the operation of the heating system, hot water supply boiler and high pressure steam boiler. Lack of water pressure at the school prevents the installation of a water softener.

PROPOSED WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM:

The proposed water supply system can roughly be divided into the following main divisions: (1) Intake, (2) Main Pipe Line, (3) Pumping Plant, (4) Water Distribution System.

Plate No. I accompanying this report, is a Plan and Profile of the survey line between the proposed location of the water supply intake and the school. This survey line does not follow the shortest distance between the proposed intake location and the school, it being necessary to diverge slightly to facilitate the running of the survey by avoiding heavy cutting through brush. Accordingly, borings shown on the profile are not all strictly on the proposed pipe line, but are sufficiently close to fairly accurately show the nature of soil to be excavated.

Plate No. II is a Plan and Profile of the proposed location of the Pipe Line between the Proposed Intake and the school. The total length of line is slightly less than the survey line. It also shows a profile of the proposed pipe line.

For the purposes of the survey the elevation of Lake Manitoba was taken as 810.0 and it will be noted that there is a rise of fifteen feet between lake level and the ground level at the school, of which eight feet occurs in the last 1500 feet adjoining the school. The distance from the outer limit of the intake to the school is 9,970 feet, of which approximately 3,000 feet between chainage 49+00 and 79+00 traverse an area covered with poplar bush. Several of
the Indians have dwellings located in this wooded area.

(1) Intake:

The governing features in connection with the intake are (a) Minimum lake elevation and (b) necessity for extension into reasonably clear water. The minimum elevation of Lake Manitoba over the past forty year period is approximately 809 as referred to our datum and the maximum slightly above 813.0. Soundings revealed that at a distance of 690 feet from waters edge, a depth of eight feet of water was obtainable. No equipment was available for us to determine the nature of whatever underlay the water and accordingly some uncertainty exists as to what difficulties will be encountered in underwater excavation. However, a boring taken some 320 feet back from the waters edge and down to elevation 805.2 showed sand and sandy loam.

It is proposed that the intake shall consist of a 4" pipe line extending from a point 690 feet beyond waters edge to a concrete lined well located at chainage 27+50. Plate No. II shows the profile of this proposed intake. It is estimated that this 4" intake line will carry by gravity a sufficient volume of water to the concrete well to enable 30 gallons of water per minute to be pumped from the well to the school. To ensure this flow it will be necessary to lay the intake pipe line at elevation 805.5 to the point where it joins waters edge. Outward from waters edge at elevation 805 the pipe line is to be supported on sunken rock filled cribbing with outer limit at approximate elevation of 804.0. Total length of 4" intake line is approximately 3,550 feet. The concrete well at Station 27+50 will be sunk to elevation 805.0 and is to be 6' 0" square. Over the well is to be built the pump house.
(2) Main Pipe Line:

The main pipe line will consist of a 3" pipe line leading from the above mentioned pump house to an underground reservoir in the immediate vicinity of the school. Plate No. II shows the profile of this proposed pipe line. To ensure protection from freezing it is considered necessary that this pipe line shall be eight feet underground between Station 27450 to 49400, 7 feet underground from Station 49400 to 79400 and 8 feet underground from 79400 to the underground reservoir. The total length of 3" pipe line will be 6,450 feet, laid in the attic of the school building.

This pipe line will discharge into an underground reservoir with a capacity of 10,000 gallons which is the estimated water requirements of the Institution for three days.

(3) Pumping System:

The most convenient layout would have the pump house at the school, the whole pipe line from school to lake being a suction line. However, it is considered that too much risk is involved with such a long suction line. The shore line of the lake affords a poor location for a pumping plant and during high water stages extensive flooding occurs to the rear of the shore line as can be noted from the profile on Plate No. I. It is proposed, therefore, to locate the pump house at Station 27450. The pump house would be built directly over the concrete well and it is hoped that a layout can be arranged so as to prevent formation of ice in the well, even though the pump house be used only every third day in winter. The location is very much exposed and it may prove difficult to protect the well from freezing, but it is considered that the difficulties can be overcome and heating be required only on
It is proposed to install one 2 H.P. engine driven Typhoon Pump to deliver thirty U.S. gallons per minute to the reservoir at the school. Pump and engine is to be mounted on the same frame.

The underground reservoir with capacity of 10,000 gallons will be located in close proximity to the extension of the present school building used as a workshop. It is proposed to utilize the 3 H.P. engine driven pump now set up in the workshop and used to pump water to the three storage tanks located in the attic of the school building. This pump will be connected to the proposed underground reservoir and the discharge line to the tanks in the attic will also be utilized as at present.

(4) Water Distribution System:

The existing distribution system consists of the three storage tanks in the attic supplying by gravity, water for general purposes throughout the school. It is proposed to utilize the same principle, replacing such piping as is necessary and adding whatever piping is required for the additional services it is proposed to install. The vertical 2" piping in the school is said to be in fair condition but horizontal lines are more or less eroded.

It is recommended that a hot water supply boiler and a high pressure steam boiler be installed. The hot water supply boiler would ensure a hot water supply during the period the heating system is not utilized and the steam boiler is rather a necessity in Indian Schools. These will involve additional connections to the water supply system.

It is also recommended a pipe connection be made from the cold water distribution line in the school building to the barn to provide a continuous water supply for stock throughout the entire year. The hog pen would be connected...
by surface piping with the feed line within the barn in order to provide a water supply at the hog pen during the non-freezing period.

ESTIMATES OF COSTS:

Time has not been taken to determine quantities of pipe connections, valves, fittings, etc., and necessarily some uncertainty must exist as to difficulties that might be encountered with excavation, particularly with underwater excavation. Underwater excavation for the intake would probably be simplified by the use of a dredge, but there is no dredge on Lake Manitoba and probably not even a scow suitable for supporting excavating machinery. A trenching machine could also be used to advantage in excavating for the pipe line, but transporting such machinery to and from the project might possibly offset the advantage over ordinary labor.

Estimates are based upon the use of cast iron pipe with flexible joints for the intake and main water line. Such pipe is made in Winnipeg, is more serviceable and less costly than either black or galvanized pipe. It also is less costly to lay.

Particulars as to the nature of excavation likely to be encountered and as determined from borings are briefly as follows:

Station 0+00 to Station 27+50 - Light sandy loam and light damp clay. This whole distance is to be excavated to a depth 4.5 feet below lake level. Borings did not reveal that difficulty would be encountered because of this fact, but some uncertainty exists, especially if excavated by hand labor.

Station 27+50 to Station 45+00 - Fairly hard clay containing some small stones.
Station 45+00 to Station 73+00 - Light sandy loam overlaying damp light sand.

Station 73+00 to Station 88+00 - Hard clay with small stones.

Station 88+00 to Water Reservoir and in vicinity of school excavation is mostly through hard clay, almost in the nature of hardpan below the 3' level.

GENERAL INFORMATION ABOUT BOILER FEED WATERS.

The analysis upon the reverse side of this blank is given in grains per imperial gallon of 2774 (approximately) cubic inches. An imperial gallon contains 70,000 grains.

To convert the figures of an analysis given in parts per 1,000,000 to grains per imperial gallon, multiply by 0.07.

To change the figures of an analysis given in grains per imperial gallon to parts per 1,000,000, divide by 0.07.

To convert grains per 1/2 S. or wine gallon to grains per imperial gallon, add one-fifth.

To convert grains per imperial gallon to grains per U.S. or wine gallon, deduct one-sixth.

To determine pounds of scale forming or incrusting solids per 1,000 gallons of water, divide grains per gallon by 7.

The incrusting solids form boiler scale.

A water containing more than 10 grains of incrusting solids is classed as a hard water.

A water containing more than 35 grains of non-incrusting solids will give trouble with foaming or priming in a locomotive boiler; although these solids may reach as high as 45 or even 60 grains per imperial gallon without causing trouble in a stationary boiler.

INFORMATION ABOUT CONSTITUENTS OF BOILER FEED WATERS.

Calcium Carbonate

(Commodity called Carbonate of Lime, Chalk or Marle. CaCO₃)

Carbonate of lime is the commonest form in which lime occurs in water. It is present in chemically pure water, but when carbonic acid is present it is found in the form of bicarbonate of lime, which is quite soluble. Bicarbonate of lime when carried into the boiler is converted into carbonate of lime when carbonic acid is driven off with the steam and normal carbonate of lime is formed. This is the form in which lime is found when the temperature reaches 90 degrees F. Carbonate of lime also does not form boiler scale, but it is responsible for a good deal of the rust which is found in the boiler. Scale formed of lime may form part of a very hard scale, when other materials are present which cement all the parts of the boiler.

Calcium Sulphate

(Commodity called sulphate of Lime, Gypsum or Plaster Paris. CaSO₄)

Sulphate of lime is present in all conditions of natural water and is responsible for the hardest kind of boiler scale. Scale formed from sulphate of lime sometimes being as hard as porcelain. If lime is present in water in sufficient quantity there is fifty pounds precipitation being in the form of heavy crystals which settle down and adhere to the sides of the boiler, forming a scale of great hardness. Scale formed of calcium sulphate sticks to the sides of a boiler much more firmly than carbonate of lime.

Calcium Chloride

Chloride of calcium is sometimes found in natural water, in which it is very soluble. It is cleaned among the corrosive minerals found in water. It does not of itself form scale, but when other sulphates are present they combine with it and precipitation sulphate is formed, which acts as described under that head.

Calcium Nitrate

Ca(NO₃)₂

Calcium nitrate rarely occurs in water, even though it be little in evidence, as the quantity is usually very small. If small does not form scale, but in the presence of sulphate of soda an exchange of acids takes place in the boiler and calcium nitrate is converted into sulphate of lime. Its action is corrosive.

Magnesium Carbonate

(sometimes called Magnesia. MgCO₃)

Magnesium carbonate is found in water for the same reasons as calcium preparation. It is then known as magnesia. It behaves in exactly the same manner as carbonate of lime. Its bi-carbonate being soluble and its tri-carbonate being practically insoluble. The remarks above, pertaining to carbonate of lime, apply here. Magnesium carbonate is used for tagging for boilers and is an excellent non-conductor of heat, but when in the form of boiler scale is on the wrong side of the shield.

Magnesium Chloride

A very objectionable mineral when present in boiler water, it being very corrosive in its action, quickly pitting and gnawing boilers which use water containing it.

Magnesium Sulphate

(Commodity known as Epsom Salts. MgSO₄)

Sulphate of magnesium is a common constituent of natural water in which it is always quite soluble. It does not of itself form boiler scale, but is broken up by the lime salts when present in the water, boiler scale being formed.

Sodium Sulphate (Glaubers Salt) and Sodium Chloride (Common Salt)

Do not form boiler scale, nor do they corrode iron, are not objectionable when present in large amounts, when they may cause foaming or priming in the boiler.

Sodium Carbonate

Does not form boiler scale nor corrode, but is objectionable when present in large quantities, as it causes foaming.

Iron

Is generally present in water in the form of bi-carbonate, but iron is extremely liable to oxidise, being oxygen is converted into iron rust, this being the cause of many boilers to burst when they are exposed to the air for a short time. Carbonate of iron cannot boil away, but remains in the boiler, and such boilers sometimes contain sulphate of iron, which is extremely corrosive.

Carbonic Acid

CO₂

Is found in all natural waters and in the same as the gas which we breathe in nodal and softer waters, and is responsible for the presence of many of the above minerals, and builds the mica solution in the water.

Silica

SiO₂

Common sand is nearly pure silica. Silica is contained in almost every water, but the greatest amount is in warm waters. It is frequently in combination with Alumina and is present in our case, is present in such small quantity that it has little to do with the formation of boiler scale.

Reactions

Water may be alkaline, neutral, or acid; it is generally found to be alkaline. Some waters are acid, although this is quite rare, except waters drawn from coal mines or from the vicinity of coal beds. Water is often treated with hydrochloric acid and with sulphuric acid, which is produced by the oxidation of the pyrites or sulphate of iron, which is always found with coal.

Suspended Matter

This is either organic or inorganic matter held in suspension in water and is very variable in quantity, depending upon the source of supply of the water and the season of the year and the season. Suspended matter forms boiler scale only by being cemented to the boiler by other materials.

Dear Sir:

We have much pleasure in submitting the following quotation for the supply and installation of the following equipment for the refrigerated rooms at the Sandy Bay Residential School, Amaranth, Manitoba.

FREEZER ROOM:
We will supply and install nine inches of fibre-glass insulation on the ceiling and three walls. The fourth wall, being the dividing wall between this room and the cooler room, will be insulated with five inches of fibre-glass. We will supply a walk-in door which will be installed in the dividing wall to give access from the cooler room to the freezer room. The floor will be insulated with six inches of corkboard and two inches of concrete over same. The interior of the room will be lined with #1 fir ceiling, painted with two coats of aluminum paint. The necessary shelves will be supplied to make a complete job.

To refrigerate this room, we will supply one bank of dale ceiling plates and a model 75FOS condensing unit, complete with all the necessary valves and fittings.

COOLER ROOM:
We will supply and install four inches of fibre-glass on the walls and ceiling. The floor will be insulated with three inches of corkboard, with two inches of concrete laid over same. For this room we will supply and install a walk-in door. The interior of this room will be lined with #1 fir ceiling, painted with two coats of aluminum paint. The room will be equipped with the necessary shelves and rails to make a complete job.

To refrigerate this room, we will supply and install a model 4000C convection coil, together with a model 75FS condensing unit, including the necessary valves and fittings.

WHEREAS The Commission, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, has agreed with the Department of Mines and Resources, to do, furnish and perform the works, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in the manner hereinafter described, in connection with the following work or works, namely:

Construct, erect, supply, install and maintain a 6900 volt transmission line together with the necessary poles, wires, transformers and other equipment required in connection therewith (hereinafter referred to as said "works") along a route from the Amaranth gypsum mine, to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, situated in and around Section Sixteen (16), in Township Eighteen (18) and Range Nine, (9), West of the Principal Meridian in the Province of Manitoba, which forms a part of "The Sandy Bay Indian Reserve".

NOW THEREFORE THIS INDENTURE WITNESSETH that the said parties hereto covenant promise and agree, each with the other, as follows:

THE DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES AGREES:

1. The Department of Mines and Resources hereby grants the Commission a license, easement or right-of-way over and upon that portion of their lands comprised by "The Sandy Bay Indian Reserve", occupied by the said works, for the purpose of permitting the Commission to adequately operate and maintain the said works in supplying electrical energy to the said buildings situated within the Sandy Bay Indian Reserve.

2. That, for and in consideration of the premises and construction, erection, supply, installation and maintenance of the works, the Department of Mines and Resources will pay to the Commission by way of contribution toward the cost of the works, the sum of Five Thousand and One Hundred Dollars ($5,100.00) and further provided, that for purposes of this contract the total cost of the works shall not include the cost of switches, additional poles, transformers or other equipment required to supply power to customers of the Commission along the said route of the transmission line.

THE COMMISSION AGREES:

1. That electrical energy supplied by the Commission under any contract or contracts between the parties hereto to supply such energy from its distribution system at the Amaranth gypsum mine, for transmission to a distribution system within the said Sandy Bay Indian Reserve, will be provided at a pressure of 6900 volts.

2. That the works shall be constructed, erected, supplied, installed and maintained by the Commission.

3. That the Commission shall supply all material, labor, transportation, supervision and services required in the construction, erection, supply, installation and maintenance of the works, for the adequate supply of electrical energy or power for the said distribution system within the Sandy Bay Indian Reserve which is now or may hereafter be erected, provided the distance between our line and any new buildings erected shall not be greater than six hundred (600) feet.
