Water Supply, Sandy Bay I.R.School
Amaranth, Manitoba.

Referring to the memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs, dated 11 October, 1949, we are now in receipt of a report from Mr. Kerr with covering letter dated 3 January, from Mr. Perrie. Duplicate copies of this report with covering letter are attached herewith.

The report indicates the present cost of installing a water line from Lake Manitoba to this school along the lines of the general design in Mr. Gow's report of September 5th, 1934, will be approximately $40,000. Mr. Perrie states that the scheme outlined in Mr. Gow's report will provide what seems to be the only really satisfactory solution to the water problem at this school.

While Mr. Perrie indicates that a change might be made in the location of the intake well with a slight saving in cost, this change will depend on conditions encountered on the Lake shore. A further investigation will be necessary before material can be ordered and before work can begin.

As water from Lake Manitoba is being used at present in the school this proposed installation of a pump and water line will not in any way improve the quality of the water available, but will save the cost of hauling water and perhaps enable a larger minimum supply to be in storage at the school with better regulation of the supply.

Estimating the life of the installation at 25 years the annual cost to cover interest and sinking fund at a 3% rate and operating costs will be:

Yearly Interest on $40,000 @ 3% $ 1,200.00
Sinking Fund Yearly Deposit 1,097.20
Operating Costs Yearly 52.80

Annual Cost $ 2,350.00

Thus, if the hauling of water at present costs more than $2,350.00 each year the installation of the proposed system would be economically advantageous. Of course, certain conveniences might result from the proposed system which cannot be expressed in money.

The attached report makes mention of the need for a high pressure laundry boiler. The estimated cost of this equipment is $1,750.00 in place, and should be considered as a separate item not included within the $40,000.00 estimated as the cost of the proposed new water system.
There appears to be a need for the installation of this water system, and if economically advantageous we recommend it be undertaken. Otherwise, it is expensive, and due to the fact that the pumphouse will be 1½ to 2 miles away from the school in an exposed location, some maintenance troubles and expense might possibly develop later if carelessness is exhibited in operation.

Chief,

Attns.

In accordance with the instructions contained in your letter of October 14th an investigation has been made into the water supply at the above school and for your information I am attaching hereto copy of a report received from Engineer W. J. Kerr in this connection.

It will be noted that Mr. Gow's report of September 5th, 1934 has been studied and that the water supply scheme as outlined in that report is quite feasible and will provide what seems to be the only really satisfactory solution to the water problem at this school. The revised estimate covering the cost of the project as outlined in Mr. Gow's report can be considered to be a fairly close one although from information just obtained, it would appear that the item of $600.00 for High Pressure Boiler should be nearer $1,600.00. However any variations in the itemized estimate would be taken care of by the 10% provided for contingencies and unforeseen and it can be considered that, to construct the water supply system as recommended by Mr. Gow, the sum of $40,000.00 would have to be provided.

In the event that the Indian Affairs Branch proposes to proceed with the project in the coming year it would be well to provide funds as above, but I am of the opinion that it may be possible to effect some considerable saving in the cost of the project by locating the well and
pump house at the lake shore rather than at Station 27/50 as shown on the profiles attached to Mr. Gow's report.

At the time of the recent inspection it was not possible to sink test holes at the lake shore but from information at present available it appears that a supply of filtered water can be made available in a well located near the shore line and if the well so located fills with water by filtration through the sand it will eliminate the necessity of installing the intake pipe to the lake and effect a saving of approximately $5,000.00 in the cost of the work.

Attached hereto are copies of the profiles that accompanied Mr. Gow's report of 1934 upon which I have indicated, in red, the recommended new location of the well and pump house.

Dear Sir:

Re: Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

In accordance with your instructions F. J. Clark and myself proceeded to Amaranth on November 25th to inspect the above school.

The school is situated about 6½ miles south east of Amaranth, Manitoba, and is about two miles from the western shore of Lake Manitoba.

The total personnel at this school is about 205 or 210, including the pupils, nuns and priests. This is the maximum complement for the school and several children had to be refused admission this fall due to the over-crowded condition. We were told by the Principal, Fr. Lambert, that he was endeavouring to have an old church changed into a day school to accommodate children from nearby and in this way ease the situation.

The school was in very good order and discipline was of a very high standard. The building's interior was very clean and well kept. Interior decorating had been done by the priests and lay brothers. All classrooms were extremely tidy. The boys' and girls' activities in the playrooms were being properly supervised and the playrooms themselves were in good condition.

The main problem at this school is to obtain some better system of delivering water. I will deal with this question first.

We had before us a copy of the "Report on Water Supply System for Sandy Bay Indian School" presented by D. B. Gow, Acting District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Supply & Reclamation Service, in August, 1934. We followed this report in detail and the project as laid out by Mr. Gow is quite feasible and any future work should follow the survey as laid down as to lines and levels.

The original water distribution has been changed since the report of 1934. The overhead tanks in the school attic have been dispensed with and pressure tanks with a total capacity of about 1,300 gallons are installed in the boiler room. The outside wells were abandoned and a 20,000 gallon concrete reservoir has been constructed approximately 50 feet from the end of the boiler room. This tank is kept filled with water by means of a tank truck which hauls the water from the lake. The truck capacity is 1,000 gallons and the water consumption in the school is about 3,000 gallons per day. It can be easily understood that, in extreme winter weather, it is a hardship to keep the water in the storage tank at a safe level.

A dug-out has been constructed and a pressure system installed to supply water to the barn and pig pen.

Mr. Gow's report was made when the prices of materials and labour were approximately half the present price, and a revised estimate of cost is attached hereto.

We are presenting an alternative to Mr. Gow's scheme, which will not only save approximately $5,000.00 but will also deliver filtered water to the school.

According to the last holes put down on the original survey, the material close to the shore line of Lake Manitoba is shingle sand and sandy loam. It is suggested that a cased well 10 x 10 be sunk near the shore line and a pump and motor installed at the same location, instead of at Sta. 27450. This would eliminate the necessity of underwater work in the lake and all of the 4" C.I. pipe which was suggested in the original estimate.

The possibility of sinking a well in the vicinity of the school is practically ruled out because of excessive quantities of sodium chloride. The former wells have been out of use for some time and were used only for flushing sewage in the school. The water level in the wells has dropped to such an extent that there is not enough water to use for flushing sewage. Lake Manitoba is the only available water source and an analysis of this water, which appears in Mr. Gow's report, shows some sodium chloride.

It is proposed to use the present storage tank for storage and to connect the 3" line from the lake directly to this tank. The Manitoba Power Commission is going to connect to this school very shortly and it is suggested...
that a transmission line be erected along the pipe line to the pumping station (approx. 9,200 feet) and electric energy, automatically controlled, be used for pumping the water.

Some type of heater will be required in the pump house to counteract freezing conditions during the winter.

An approximate cost of this method is as follows:

Timber crib well - Excav. & constr. $1,500.00
Material for well and pump house 800.00

$35,363.00

We have included the cost of a high pressure boiler in our estimate. This could be installed in the boiler room beside the present furnace and boiler.

Our report is not as complete as it might have been, but after one day's stay at Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, we were forced to leave due to inclement weather and the possibility of being snowed in.

Trusting that I have given you sufficient information for your requirements, I remain,

Yours truly,

The attached report makes mention of the need for a high pressure laundry boiler. The estimated cost of this equipment is $1,750.00 in place, and should be considered as a separate item not included within the $40,000.00 estimated as the cost of the proposed new water system.
There appears to be a need for the installation of this water system, and if economically advantageous we recommend it be undertaken. Otherwise, it is expensive, and due to the fact that the pumphouse will be 1/2 to 2 miles away from the school in an exposed location, some maintenance troubles and expense might possibly develop later if carelessness is exhibited in operation.

In the event that the Indian Affairs Branch proposes to proceed with the project in the coming year it would be well to provide funds as above, but I am of the opinion that it may be possible to effect some considerable saving in the cost of the project by locating the well and...

Dear Sir:

Re: Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

In accordance with your instructions F. J. Clark and myself proceeded to Amaranth on November 25th to inspect the above school.

The school is situated about 6½ miles southeast of Amaranth, Manitoba, and is about two miles from the western shore of Lake Manitoba.

The total personnel at this school is about 205 or 210, including the pupils, nuns and priests. This is the maximum complement for the school and several children had to be refused admission this fall due to the over-crowded condition. We were told by the Principal, Fr. Lambert, that he was endeavouring to have an old church changed into a day school to accommodate children from nearby and in this way ease the situation.

The school was in very good order and discipline was of a very high standard. The building's interior was very clean and well kept. Interior decorating had been done by the priests and lay brothers. All classrooms were extremely tidy. The boys' and girls' activities in the playrooms were being properly supervised and the playrooms themselves were in good condition.

The main problem at this school is to obtain some better system of delivering water. I will deal with this question first.

We had before us a copy of the "Report on Water Supply System for Sandy Bay Indian School" presented by D. B. Gow, Acting District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service, in August, 1934. We followed this report in detail and the project as laid out by Mr. Gow is quite feasible and any future work should follow the survey as laid down as to lines and levels.

The original water distribution has been changed since the report of 1934. The overhead tanks in the school attic have been dispensed with and pressure tanks with a total capacity of about 1,300 gallons are installed in the boiler room. The outside wells were abandoned and a 20,000 gallon concrete reservoir has been constructed approximately 50 feet from the end of the boiler room. This tank is kept filled with water by means of a tank truck which hauls the water from the lake. The tank capacity is 1,000 gallons and the water consumption in the school is about 3,000 gallons per day. It can be easily understood that, in extreme winter weather, it is a hardship to keep the water in the storage tank at a safe level.

A dug-out has been constructed and a pressure system installed to supply water to the barn and pig pen.

Mr. Gow's report was made when the prices of materials and labour were approximately half the present price, and a revised estimate of cost is attached hereto.

We are presenting an alternative to Mr. Gow's scheme, which will not only save approximately $5,000.00 but will also deliver filtered water to the school.

According to the last holes put down on the original survey, the material close to the shore line of Lake Manitoba shows sand and sandy loam. It is suggested that a cribbed well 10 x 10 be sunk near the shore line and a pump and motor installed at this same location instead of at Sta. 2750. This would eliminate the necessity of underwater work in the lake and all of the 4" C.I. pipe which was suggested in the original estimate.

The possibility of sinking a well in the vicinity of the school is practically ruled out because of excessive quantities of sodium chloride. The former wells have been out of use for some time and were used only for flushing sewage in the school. The water level in the wells has dropped to such an extent that there is not enough water to use for flushing sewage. Lake Manitoba is the only available water source and an analysis of this water, which appears in Mr. Gow's report, shows some sodium chloride.

It is proposed to use the present storage tank for storage and to connect the 3" line from the lake directly to this tank. The Manitoba Power Commission is going to connect to this school very shortly and it is suggested
that a transmission line be erected along the pipe line to the pumping station (approx. 9,200 feet) and electric energy, automatically controlled, be used for pumping the water.

Some type of heater will be required in the pump house to counteract freezing conditions during the winter.

An approximate cost of this method is as follows:

Our report is not as complete as it might have been, but after one day's stay at Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, we were forced to leave due to inclement weather and the possibility of being snowed in.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Sandy Bay Residential School.

A letter to you from the Director Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, dated the 15th March, and bearing your signature of the 16th was accompanied by tenders obtained by Regional Supervisor Davis for electrical revisions at the above.

Mr. Davis had forwarded recommendations from the Inspection Branch of the Manitoba Power Commission under cover of his letter to the Indian Affairs Branch dated 1st March, 1950.

These recommendations and the tenders are not based on conventional specifications, and no drawings appear to have been furnished to the parties tendering.

This office has been asked to comment on the tenders and to recommend action on the award of a contract. Since no request for wiring revisions was made to this office, and we are unfamiliar with conditions at the school, an inspection trip will be necessary before Major MacKay can be furnished with our comment.

We have therefore instructed our electrical engineer Kosnar, now in the field, to stop over in Winnipeg on his return from Jasper, interview Supervisor Davis, and carry out an inspection at the school, on which to base a report and recommendation.

Mr. Kosnar should be back in Ottawa by April 5th.

With reference to our memorandum to you dated the 25th of March, you are advised that our electrical engineer interviewed Mr. Davis, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Manitoba, and carried out the inspection at the above.

2. After examining the tenders submitted our officer contacted Colonel Neary in Ottawa by telephone regarding the extent of the work to be carried out and he requested that our investigation include lighting alterations as well as the work necessary to change-over from the present direct current supply provided by the diesel generating unit at the school to the alternating current supply of the Manitoba Power Commission.

3. The Manitoba Power Commission prepared an electrical drawing showing new service and distribution equipment required and also electrical controls for new power-driven laundry and baking equipment which the school Principal had apparently requested or desired. It was on this plan and a report of their inspection, which included outbuildings, that the contractors based their quotations.

4. In a discussion with the Principal it appeared that it was not definitely established that the equipment shown on the Commission's plan requiring electrical connections and controls would be provided. During a discussion with Colonel Neary and Mr. Phelan of the Indian Affairs Branch, it was established that no requests for the above mentioned equipment were on file in Ottawa, and concurrence was given to our suggestion that until such time as a decision was reached in this connection, provision would be made for this equipment only in the service capacity. In the interim the diesel engine, which at present is used to drive the D.C. generator and line shaft for the existing equipment will be retained to power the line shaft only.

5. The lighting generally is not good at the school and improvements were recommended, particularly in areas where the seeing tasks require high levels of illumination. Colonel Neary concurred in making the necessary alterations and additions to the lighting, but requested that changes be limited to areas such as classrooms where good illumination is a requisite.
6. It is necessary to carry out wiring in several of the Outbuildings to bring them up to Canadian Electrical Code Standards, and this together with changes necessary for the three (3) wire outside distribution system will be included in the work to be done.

7. It was noted from the tenders submitted that all contractors did not base their bids on similar work and we are at present engaged in the preparation of plans and specifications which will form a common basis upon which the contractors can submit competitive tenders.

8. Upon completion, blueprints of our drawings and copies of our specifications will be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch for transmission to Mr. Davis for calling of tenders.

Further reference to your Army message dated August 30, 1950 regarding the erection of a piggery and manual training building at Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

Father Lambert called at my office in July and I wrote the Department under file No. 149/6-1-584 dated July 27, 1950, asking for information regarding the location etcetera of these buildings.

Apparently Mr. Doucett visited the school last time he was west. I understood from Father Lambert that some of the naffs etcetera had been shipped to them for this purpose. As soon as I can get time I will visit Sandy Bay and take the matter up with you further on my return.

Mr. R.S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of
Indian Agencies,
537 Dominion Public Building,

Re: Sandy Bay Residential School
Your File 149/6-1-584

We have your letter of the 31st ultimo with reference to the request which you have received from the Principal of the above school for authority to proceed with the erection of a carpentry shop and piggery.

No authority has been given for the erection of either of the above mentioned buildings, and in passing I might say that Mr. Doucet did not visit the school within the past year. In this connection I would refer you to our signal of August 30th.

We have received direct from Father Lambert a requisition for the materials for the carpentry shop and also for the piggery. We are prepared to supply the material for either of these buildings, but not for both of them on the understanding that the labour will be supplied by the school staff without cost to the Department.

Please consult the Principal and advise which building he chooses to erect this year.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Ottawa, October 20th, 1931.

Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the September quarter return of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School and it is noted that the Principal has, apparently, changed the register numbers of some of the pupils. It is most important that the register number given a pupil on admission should be retained for the whole period of residence and dropped when such pupil is discharged. To explain the matter more fully, I give the following statement:

| Register Number | Quarter Return | September Quarter Return |
|-----------------|----------------|--------------------------|
| 141             | Alex Deaffie   | Louis Walker             |
| 142             | R. Levasseur   | Alex Deaffie             |
| 143             | Stephen Beaulieu | Rupert Levasseur       |
| 144             | R. J. Houle    | Stephen Beaulieu         |
| 145             | - - - - - - - - | Rodrigue J. Houle        |
| 0142            | A. L. Walker   | Mary Summer              |
| 0143            | Mary Summer    | V. Levasseur             |
| 0144            | V. Levasseur   | Genevieve Richard        |
| 0145            | G. Richard     | A. Roulette              |
| 0146            | A. Roulette    | A. Walker                |

I would appreciate your taking up this matter with the Principal and have the return properly made out, keeping in mind that the Department desires the register numbers given pupils on the June quarter return retained, as the numbers appearing on that return correspond with the numbers entered on the application forms which are on the Department's file.

I may add that no application or certificate of health has yet been received for R. J. Houle. There does not appear to have been any application submitted for Louis Walker. Possibly, this is a mistake. The Principal may mean Louise Walker and, if so, she should be shown on the section of the return on which the girls' names are entered.

To assist the Principal in his financing, a cheque for $2,000., being part payment of the September quarter grant, is forwarded under separate cover and any balance will be paid when the amended return is received.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

S. J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

September 5th, 1932.

William Thomas Beaulieu, Sandy Bay I. Reserve, Man.
(10) Indian Act.

With reference to the above matter, I have the honour to report that at 10:45 a.m. on Saturday the 3rd instant a long distance call was received from J. White, Esq., Indian Agent of Portage la Prairie, to the effect that the night of Friday the 2nd instant a boy named William Thomas Beaulieu had gone to the Indian Residential School at Sandy Bay I. Reserve, and, against the wishes of Rev. Father O. Chagnon, Principal, taken his son Clifford Beaulieu, home from the school for the week-end, stating that the boy was lonesome and he would return him to school on Monday.

It was desired to have this boy returned to the school before Monday, as if allowed to remain away from the school it was felt that the parents of other children attending the school would want to have their children home, and thereby a great deal of trouble would be caused during the present teaching year.

Briefly the reason for desiring action taken is as follows:

"In the past it has been the practice at Sandy Bay Indian Residential School to allow the children whose parents reside at the Reserve to go to their homes from Friday until Monday. This has proved to be a very unsatisfactory arrangement, in the past the children have returned to school the majority of them being dirty and verminous, also in numerous instances there has been children remaining away from school until Wednesday and Thursday of the following week.

It was therefore found necessary to discontinue the privilege, and before the summer holidays all parents were informed that all of the children in residence must remain at the school."

In view of the request of the Indian Agent, and with a view to possibly avoiding any further trouble from this source, it was arranged that Rev. Father O. Chagnon, Principal, of Sandy Bay Indian Residential School would transport the writer to Sandy Bay Indian Reserve in order that steps might be taken to have Clifford Beaulieu returned to the School before Monday, thus establishing that the children must remain at the School as ordered by the Principal.

At the early p.m. same date I left Gladstone accompanying Rev. Father O. Chagnon in his private car and proceeded to where William Thomas Beaulieu was camped by the house of William Thomas Beaulieu Sr. We located Clifford Beaulieu, but at this time the parent was not available, and we awaited his return.

Upon his return I interviewed William Thomas Beaulieu, and upon it being pointed out to him that Clifford Beaulieu should not have left, or been taken away from the school without the permission of Father Chagnon, he intimated that he now knew that and had intended to return the boy at 4:00 p.m. this date. He was quite agreeable for the boy to return to the school with us.

P.T.C.
In conclusion I might state that as far as I can ascertain there is no "truant officer" appointed at Sandy Bay Indian Reserve and this patrol was made chiefly to avoid Beaulieu establishing his presence here. It is doubtful if some steps had not been taken to assure that boy Clifford Beaulieu's return to school before Monday, then other parents would go to the school and take their children away against the wishes and without the consent of the Principal.

The fact that this boy returned to the School on Saturday will undoubtedly establish the rights of the Principal of the school, as guardian of the children in residence, against the parents who persist in so far as their remaining at the school is concerned.

Whereas, as before stated, if this boy had been allowed to remain away from the school until the date that his parent stated he would bring him back, it would tend to lessen the authority of the Principal of the School.

Respectfully submitted.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a report from the R.C.M.P., in connection with action they recently took in returning Clifford Beaulieu to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

It appears that the management of this school has been in the habit of allowing certain pupils to go home from Saturday to Monday but that they have discontinued this practice recently. The above-mentioned boy's father came to the school and took him home in spite of the objections of the Principal and the R.C.M.P. were, apparently, requested to have him returned, which they did.

The Department has never approved of pupils of Indian residential schools being allowed home over Sunday and we are pleased to note that this practice has been discontinued at the Sandy Bay School.

You should give the Principal every possible assistance in this matter by pointing out to the Indian parents concerned that it is in the best interests of their children to remain in the school.

Sir;-

Re: 126-9-10, Ottawa, November 3rd, 1932.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter in reference to the two truants of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School and also wish to say that I have informed the Reverend Principal of the Department's decision in this matter.

May I again be permitted to refer to this matter, as it is my experience that when truancy once becomes epidemic in a school it is very difficult to eradicate.

The Sandy Bay Residential School is situated in the centre of the Sandy Bay Reserve and it is very easy for a pupil to leave school without the school staff being aware of it. The child when once on the reserve is harboured by the Indians and if the child can tell a story of a whipping, it becomes quite a problem to get the pupil back to school.

I firmly believe that if the two boys in question were transferred to another school as a disciplinary measure, and the two boys are chronic truants, I believe that it would tend to stop truancy from becoming epidemic in this school.

I beg to request that the Department will reconsider their decision in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ambrose SUTHERLAND,-Sandy Bay Indian Reserve, Man.,
-Truancy-(Sec10)-Indian Act.

29-10-32

(1). With reference to the above matter, in the
p.m. of Saturday the 29th inst., a long distance call was
received at this Detachment from J. Waite, the Indian Agent
of Portage La Prairie, to the effect that a call had been
received from Reverend Father Chagnon, Principal of the Indian
Residential School at Sandy Bay Indian Reserve complaining
of truancy on the part of some of the pupils at this School,
and it was desired to have the matter investigated, and the
Truants returned to School.

5-11-32

(2). On Saturday the 5th inst., a patrol was made
to Sandy Bay Indian Reserve per police car #1245, and I pro-
ceeded to the Indian Residential School.
Upon interviewing Father Chagnon he stated that three
pupils had been absent, two had been returned to the
school by their respective parents, and there was now only
one pupil absent, Ambrose SUTHERLAND, 15 years old.
From enquiries made by Father Chagnon this pupil had been
staying part of the time with Mrs James Harris and one
Goodmundson near Langruth.
But while at the school it was learned from Joe Beaulieu
that this youth was now back on the Reserve, and had been
staying part of the time at Norbert Beaulieu, Albert Beaulieu
and Frank Deslauriers.
Accompanied by Father Chagnon a patrol was made to these res-
pective places, and Ambrose SUTHERLAND was playing near the
home of Albert BEAULIEU, but upon seeing us approach he ran
off into the bush, and while a search was made he was not lo-
cated.
Father Chagnon suggested that he be left as it would be use-
less to try and catch him in the bush, and arrangements were
made with the respective persons with whom Sutherland has
been staying, to hold him on his return, and report to the
school, in order that this youth may be returned to the school.

(3). No further police services being required
in this connection, I left the Reserve at 4.30 p.m., and return-
ed to Detachment.

Respectfully submitted,

October 16th, 1933.

Delvina BEAULIEU, (Treaty Indian) Candy Bay Residential School, Marquis P.O., Manitoba.

Juvenile Delinquent - Truancy & Theft of Clothing.

Section 10 Indian Act -- Sec 386 C.C.C.

In reference to the above I beg to report that on this date a communication was received from Rev O.CHAGNON, Principal of the above school, to the effect that during the past month, Delvina BEAULIEU, pupil of the school, had run away on three occasions, that she had stolen clothing on two of these occasions, and that she was still away from the school.

On this date, a phone call was received from G.W.Langdon, Esq., J.P., Langruth, Man., to the effect that Rev. O.CHAGNON had laid information before him charging Delvina BEAULIEU with theft and truancy, and that the girl was missing and could not be located.

On this date, whilst enroute to Amaranth per Pol car 1245 on other Police duties, the writer patrolled to Sandy Bay Ind. Res. and apprehended Delvina BEAULIEU, escorting her to Amaranth, where Police court was to be held. Rev. O.CHAGNON was present at the time, who stated that some of the clothing stolen by the girl, had been returned, the articles which had been stolen consisting of a girl's hat, dress, and a pair of boy's pants.

Delvina BEAULIEU was brought before J.G.Crawford, Esq., D.J.J. of Gladstone, Man., W.D. Card, Esq., Crown Attorney, C.J.D. appears for the Crown on the "Theft of Clothing" charge. The charges against the accused, however, were not read to the girl, W.D. Card, Esq.; and Rev. O.CHAGNON having conferred on the matter, Rev Chagnon deciding to give the accused another chance at the School.

In view of the fact that Rev Chagnon decided to give the accused another chance, the information in this matter is being held "Sine Die"; and in the event of this girl giving further trouble, she could then be dealt with in this connection also. This matter will thus be considered temporarily closed.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith for the consideration of the Department, the Application for Admission to the Indian Residential School at Sandy Bay, of Joseph Henry Desjarlais, son of Mrs George Desjarlais, No; 63 of the Rolling River Band. This boy is illegitimate, the father, now dead, being Max Spence, No; 73 of the same band. The boy was admitted to treaty on the authority of Departmental letter No; 3-106 dated 14th July 1931.

I am also forwarding the Applications for Admission to the Brandon Residential School, of Annie Merle Flett, and Agnes Marion Flett, children of McKay Flett, No; 60 of the Keeseekeowenin Band. These children have for a year or more been attending the Elphinstone Consolidated School, but the father died last June, which altered their circumstances somewhat, and the mother was unable to provide for these and the other children. An older half sister, Elsie McLaren, is taking Normal at Brandon, and living at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to children sixteen years of age and over in the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

I am inclined to feel from your letter that you have taken a wrong impression from the Deputy Superintendent's circular of the 15th ultimo. Please read this circular again and you will note that it simply pointed out that the Indian Act requires permission to be secured when it is desired to keep children over sixteen years of age in a residential school. The Department fully realizes that there are often very good reasons for keeping children after the age mentioned, but, as stated above, permission should be secured. We are prepared to give favourable consideration to representations made by principals with regard to retaining children over sixteen years.

The practice which the Department desires followed in future is that at the end of each academic year the Principal should prepare a list of children sixteen years of age and over. He should state definitely those whom he considers should be retained for a further period and give his reasons for this action in each individual case. This report should be forwarded to the Department through the office of your local Indian Agent.

In accordance with the above, you should at once prepare a list of children sixteen years of age and over in the Sandy Bay School, giving their names and register numbers, and, in the case of those whom you consider should be retained for a further period, you should request such permission and give your reasons for making the request. This should be forwarded to the Department through the office of your local Indian Agent.

Your obedient servant,

Philip Phelan,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

GENERAL PATROL to Sandy Bay Indian Reserve, Man.

(Re: Indian Act)

1-12-34

1. Reference the above, in the a.m. of this date the writer left Gladstone for Pol. Car Code #1245, accompanied and assisted by Cst J.F. Klassen, and patrolled to Sandy Bay Indian Reserve for the purpose of making a General Patrol of the Reserve, and making further investigation in various outstanding matters.

2. A patrol was made to the residence of the "farm instructor", and A.C. Benson, farm instructor, was interviewed, but stated that everything was quiet and orderly on the Reserve at the present time. No complaints requiring attention had been received by him.

3. A patrol was also made to the Indian Residential School, and Rev. O.M. Chagnon, Principal, was interviewed, and other than one pupil who has been absent during all of the present term, there was no matters requiring attention.

4. Alice Grace Mosseau, (ward of James Cook), has not attended School since the opening of the present term. James Cook is at present staying in the Gladstone District, and steps will be taken to interview him in the near future with a view to ascertaining the reason that this Child has not returned to School.

5. During the course of this patrol no infractions of the law were detected, and returned to Detachment in the p.m. same date.

Dear Sir:—

There are two truant boys on the Lake Manitoba Reserve from the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. Their names are Alex Deaffy and Norman Maytwashing. These children will have to be returned to the School immediately. Will you kindly visit the Reserve at your earliest convenience, and have them returned.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) J. Waite.
Indian Agent.

2. In the early a.m. of April 1st, 1935, I left Eriksdale by horse livery, and proceeded to the Lake Manitoba Indian Reserve, and made enquiries for Alex Deaffy and Norman Maytwashing. I found out from the Farm Instructor, Mr. C.L. Mitchell, that the former boy had been returned to the School at Sandy Bay, a few days previous, the chief from that Reserve, Louie Prince, having come over for him.

3. I located Norman Maytwashing at the home of his father, John Baptiste Maytwashing, the father was away. The boy had been home since February 22nd, 1935. He was very reluctant to leave, and hung on to the bedstead in the shack. I however got him into the cutter, and we started off across Lake Manitoba, by horse livery, arriving at Amaranth late in the evening.

4. East from Amaranth, we travelled through the Sandy Bay Indian Reserve, to the Indian Residential School, where I interviewed the Principle, Father O. Chagnon. He informed me that the other boy, Alex Deaffy, was back at the institution already. Norman Maytwashing was handed over to the Principle by me, and I obtained a receipt for him. The livery driver and myself stayed at the school overnight, and left there in the early a.m. of April 2nd, 1935, arriving at Eriksdale at 11-48 p.m.

5. The following expenses were incurred:

April 1st/End. Horse livery from Eriksdale to Lake Manitoba Indian Reserve, to Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, via Amaranth, and return to Eriksdale. 130 miles at $2.50 per mile........................................... $16.25
April 1/2. Lunch, lunch, and dinner.......................... 1.50

Reverend Sir:

The Department is informed that Margaret Rattlesnake, illegitimate daughter of Angus Bone and Mrs. Rattlesnake, who were recently admitted as members of the Keesekocovenin Band, was taken to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, early this month, by a priest from the school, during the absence of the father, Angus Bone. Angus Bone objects to this girl being placed in a Catholic institution against his wishes and desires to have her educated in the Birtle Indian Residential School.

I would point out that this girl should not have been taken to your school until an application for her admission had been forwarded to the Department and the necessary authority granted for her admittance. In view of the fact that there is a question raised as to the religious denomination of the school in which this child should be placed, I have to request that you will have her returned to her home on the Keesekocovenin Reserve at the earliest possible date. After she arrives at home, the local Agent will be requested to ascertain definitely the religious belief to which she belongs, prepare an application for her admission and have her examined by a doctor and then forward the application to the Department, who will decide the school in which she should be placed. I have to request that you will see that this girl is returned to her home at an early date.

Further re this subject I have to state as follows: On the 24th instant whilst in the Sandy Bay dist. on other duties I learned that this truant was being harbored by Louis Prince, Chief of the Sandy Bay Band.

The writer and Cst. R. E. Bradley forthwith proceeded to the Prince premises but found that the boy had again escaped from the house before we got there. The truant's father was there and on asking him where the boy was he said "You can go to hell, I'm busy here and you have no right to come here to accuse me." After informing him that we would only be back in about an hour and that he should locate his son and turn him over we left on other duties. We called at the Sandy Bay Residential School where I arranged with Father Chagnon that should Albert Beaulieu, the father, decide to bring the boy to the school he would take him in and notify this office.

We subsequently returned to the Prince abode. The father had also left and could not be located. Mrs. Beaulieu, the mother, was present and I served on her a notification as provided for in Sec. 10 of the Indian Act. The father had been previously notified verbally. The mother was served both verbally and in writing. She however refused, at the instigation of the Chief, to accept the service. I put the paper down at her feet whereupon Chief Prince picked it up and threw it into the police car at the same time stating that we had no business coming onto the Reserve without a permit from the Indian Agent and threatened to forcibly put us off. By that time he had gathered some 10 to 12 other Indians with him. I handed the paper back to him and advised him to place it back where he had picked it up. He refused to do so by again throwing the paper at me.

Other members of the band that had gathered, apparently the Chief's cronies, refused to divulge their names and as the writer is not very familiar with the members of the Sandy Bay I cannot say who they were. I would however recognize all, or nearly all of them, if I saw them again.

The Chief is a particularly obnoxious type of individual and has absolutely no respect for law or order. He admitted harboring the truant in question and stated that we had no "god-damn business" trying to take him away.

It would appear that Prince, in the actions above described, was obstructing a peace officer in the execution of his duty and should be prosecuted; otherwise he and his followers will get out of control. I might say here that only a small percentage of the members of the Sandy Bay Band have any use for him. He is unpopular with most of them.

Further; I have no doubt that Albert Beaulieu will refuse to produce hoy within the 3 day time limit and if he does so refuse I suggest that action be taken against him under the provisions of the Act. P.T.O.

Sir-

I received your letter No.126-9-10 of the 4th inst regarding the children of Angus Bone of the Keeseeboowenin Band.

On the 26th of October I forwarded to you the form applying for admission to the Birtle Residential School of George Rattlesnake, one of the children in question, and I have the application form for the admittance of Margaret Rattlesnake, duly filled in and signed by Angus Bone, but I have not forwarded same to you as she could not be medically examined until she was returned to the Reserve.

Angus Bone has certainly supported these children, and is still doing so. He was brought up as a Presbyterian, and still claims to be one, and I am almost sure that there is a record of his baptism in the Presbyterian faith in the Church at Alphinstone.

Both Angus Bone and Chief George Bone complained to me about the Priest taking Margaret to School without his consent. Angus Bone signed the application forms for both children in my presence, and they were witnessed by his brother, Henry Bone. Mr White, the Missionary on the Reserve, was also present when Angus signed the forms, and assured me that he was a Presbyterian and wished to have the children brought up in the Presbyterian faith.

I am also sure that the Presbyterian Church have brought no pressure to bear on Angus Bone regarding his children. One girl of Angus Bone's has attended the Birtle School for some time, and both Angus and Mrs Rattlesnake requested me to take Margaret to Birtle School sometime before she was admitted as a member of the Band.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, April 1st, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of another application for the admission of Margaret Rattlesnake to the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. This application form is signed by both the father and the mother and states that the child's religion is Roman Catholic. The medical health form has been signed by Doctor Lerner. As there appears to be some doubt regarding the religious auspices under which the Rattlesnake children should be educated the Department has decided to request Inspector Hamilton to look into this matter fully on the occasion of his next visit to your agency.

While the admission of George Rattlesnake to the Birtle Indian Residential School was approved by official letter of October 27th, last, his name does not appear on the December quarter return and it is presumed that he has not entered that school. He should remain at home with his parents until after Inspector Hamilton reports and our decision has been given.

We are informed that Margaret Rattlesnake is at present in the Sandy Bay School and it has been decided to approve her admission temporarily until the end of June. In the meantime, as stated above, we will have Inspector Hamilton's report.

Frequently, cases arise where it is doubtful under what religious auspices the children should be educated. In all such circumstances, it is expected that our officials will investigate fully and report the facts for our decision.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes.
Secretary.

Ottawa, April 1st, 1937.

Dear Sir,

The Department has had considerable correspondence with Mr. A. G. Smith, Indian Agent, Birtle, Man., with reference to the religious auspices under which certain children named Rattlesnake should be educated. These children were accepted as members of the Keeseekeowenin Band last September.

On the occasion of your next visit to the Birtle Agency, you should interview the father and mother and make full inquiries regarding the religion of this family.

You will note sub-section 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act. The intention of this section is that an Indian child should attend a school conducted under the auspices of the church with which the child and its parents are affiliated. The Department believes that strict adherence to this rule is in the best interests of its wards. Whenever any disagreement arises regarding the religious auspices under which a child should be educated, we endeavour to ascertain the religion of the parents and the real wish of the father at the time application is made for the admission of the child to a residential school.

In the case under discussion, there is disagreement regarding the religious auspices under which the child should be educated and, as mentioned above, the Department desires you to fully investigate the matter and report.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

re Sandy Bay Indian Residential School

Two men employed at the above school, Mr. Cahill and Mr. Normandin, have each five children of school age. There naturally is no public school district on the reserve. I have asked the Principal of the Residential School, Father O. Chagnon, if these children cannot be accommodated in the classes in the school. He suggests that their classes now are overcrowded. Hon. Mr. Schultz has asked that I write you to see whether you think it is possible for these children to be provided for in the Residential School classes.

Yours truly,

R. Fletcher  
Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, December 1, 1937.

Dear Dr. Fletcher:

I have discussed with Father Plourde the desirability of having provision made for the Cahill and Normandin children at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, and he has promised me that he will communicate immediately with the Principal in respect to the matter.

I have been wondering if it would be possible to have the Correspondence Branch supply these children with the regular public school lessons. If this suggestion appeals to you, you might intimate to Father O. Chagnon that the Department will be prepared to forward from time to time copies of the regular correspondence courses, on the understanding that provision for the accommodation of these children will be made at his school and, in addition to this, a certain amount of direction and instruction by a member of the school staff.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. Robert Fletcher, B.A., LL.D.,
Deputy Minister of Education,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

Joseph Dan Gaywis of the Rolling River Band, and his family were all baptised as members of the Presbyterian Church about two weeks ago, by the Rev. E.H. Lockhart Principal of the Birtle Indian School. Previously Gaywis was a Roman Catholic although his wife was a Presbyterian and one girl, Elizabeth, is a pupil in the Birtle Indian School.

Alec Gaywis, a son of the above, was admitted to the Sandy Bay Residential School as a pupil, in the fall of 1936 I think. Shortly after going to school the boy took ill and was brought home by his Father. Since then he has been at home as he was not very strong and his Father would not give his consent to the boy's tonsils being removed as recommended by the Medical Officer of the Sandy Bay School. The boy seems to be in better health now however, and the parents desire to have him admitted to the Birtle Indian School Residential School as a pupil. This School as you know is a Presbyterian School.

I have no copy of the application form for admission into the Sandy Bay Residential School of this boy, so cannot give you the exact date of admission.

Gaywis did not like the Sandy Bay School and his change to the Presbyterian Faith may have been prompted by his desire to have the boy transferred. We cannot say that that is the case however.

Please advise me if you approve of the transfer of this boy to the Birtle School.

Yours truly,

A.D. Smith
Indian Agent

May 28th, 1939

ALFRED BEAULIEU, JOE HULE and James MUSSEAU (Treaty Indians) runaway boys from Ste Rose du Lac N.W., The Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, Sandy Bay La., Manitoba.

I have to report that at 9:00 A.M. this date I received a telephone call from Rev.Father COMBS of The Sandy Bay La., Residential School. Father COMBS informed me that the above mentioned three Treaty Indian boys had run away from the school at 6:00 P.M. 7-4-39. ALFRED BEAULIEU age 14 years and JAMES MUSSEAU age 11 years were both from the Red and Flow La., while JOE HULE age 11 years was from Long Plains La. Father COMBS requested that I locate the boys and return them to the Residential School at Sandy Bay La.

I proceeded from Ste Rose du Lac on this date at 9:00 A.M. per Pat. Code No.285 to Ebb and Flow La., Manitoba. At this point I located the above three boys.

BEAULIEU claimed that he run away because he was going to be punished. JOE HULE claimed that BEAULIEU asked him to go with him, and he went. JAMES MUSSEAU claimed that he was going to be punished for breaking something on a windmill.

On arrival at Ebb and Flow La., I proceeded from Ebb and Flow La., accompanying the above three boys to Sandy Bay La. On arrival at Sandy Bay La., Residential School I handed the three boys over to Father COMBS. I returned to Ebb and Flow La., with ALADIN. On my arrival at the Ebb and Flow La., I was informed by ALADIN, Mr. ADAM School Teacher on the Reserve that Mary (Mme. MILLE) MUSSEAU was very sick on the Reserve, and requested me to take her to Dr. GENDREAU, M.D., at Ste Rose du Lac. I then proceeded from Ebb and Flow La., in company with Mary (Mme. MILLE) MUSSEAU, arriving at Ste Rose du Lac at 12:00 P.M. (noon). I ordered her to be taken to the Ste Rose Hospital. In company with Dr.GENDREAU I handed over Mrs. MUSSEAU to the Ste Rose Hospital.

Return copies attached for the information of the Department Concerned, and J.WAITE, Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie N.W.T.

Released Feb. ONE WAY, 65 miles.

J. WAITE,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie.

on Friday April 15th, 1940 SUTHERLAND left Nibb and flew I.R. for Dog Creek I.R., across Lake Nibb and flew and Lake Manitoba. Enquiries were made this date at Nibb and flew I.R. He did not meet Edwin SUTHERLAND on the lakes. According to FLEET the ice was safe if one knew where to go, but it was very dangerous if you did not know where to go on the ice. Alfred Beaillieu et al., Indians,
Sandy Bay I.R. School,
Runaway boys.

(Keelwood Det. Case)

25-4-40

1. Relative to the above, and further to the marginally noted report I have to report that on this date I was informed by Mr. Adam of the Reddy Creek P.O. District Manitoba that he had heard that Alfred Beaillieu had been to the Nip and Flow I.R. Man., along with another boy by the name of Sutherland. Beaillieu was supposed to have come to the Ste Rose du Lac District to where his father Simon Beaillieu was working, and Sutherland was supposed to have left Nip and Flow I.R. for Dog Creek I.R.

At 7:00 P.M., I proceeded from Ste Rose du Lac in company with Mr. Adam to the R.M. of Ste Rose Manitoba. The family of Simon Beaillieu was located on the farm of Mr. Vanport, I was informed by Mrs. Beaillieu that her son Alfred had arrived from Sandy Bay I.R. School, and had been living with them. She claimed that he had left a short time before, and did not know where he had gone. A search around the area was made with no results. It appeared that as soon as Alfred saw the Police Car he went into the bush, and was hiding. The area was checked until dark with no results. I informed Mrs. Beaillieu that she was to notify her husband as soon as he returned that he was to bring Alfred to the Detachment Office at Ste Rose du Lac.

I returned to Ste Rose du Lac at 9:30 P.M.

26-4-40

At 9:00 A.M., this date Simon Beaillieu had not showed up with Alfred. It appeared to me that Alfred had not returned to their camp that night.

I notified the O.C. Dauphin Sub-Div., that I had to leave for the Nip and Flow I.R. at once as a prairie fire was burning, and that the timber on the Reserve had to be protected at once. I informed the O.C. that I had instructed Simon Beaillieu to bring Alfred to this point when he located him, and when he arrived the Dauphin Sub-Div. office would be notified by my wife.

During the P.M., while I was at Nip and Flow I.R., on other Police duties Sgt. McDonald, No. 11024 and Sgt. Tisdale, No. 11993 arrived at the Reserve with Alfred Beaillieu, and handed him over to me to take to Sandy Bay I.R. School.

I proceeded from Nip and Flow I.R. to Sandy Bay I.R., escorting Alfred Beaillieu. On arrival at the school I handed Alfred Beaillieu over to Rev. Father Chagnon at Sandy Bay I.R. School. I returned to Nip and Flow I.R. at midnight.

According to Alfred Beaillieu Edwin Sutherland had came to Nip and Flow I.R. along with him, and

Man. April 24th., 1940.

Alfred BEAULIEU, et al., (Indians)
Sandy Bay I.R. School,
Runaway boys. (Kelwood Det. case.)

1. Reference the above named and to Wm. & Alfred ROULETTE, Jimmie and Edwin SUTHERLAND, pupils of the Sandy Bay I.R. I have to report as follows:

2. In the p.m. of the 23rd. inst. Rev. Father Chagnon, 1/c Sandy Bay Indian School, reported to this office that the five above named Indian boys ran away from the school in the a.m. of the 23rd. inst. Their homes being as follows:- Wm. & Alfred ROULETTE, 6 miles n.e. of Gladstone, their father being Pascal ROULETTE; Jimmie & Edwin SUTHERLAND, Dog Creek I.R., their father being George SUTHERLAND and Alfred BEAULIEU, Ochre River, his father being Simon BEAULIEU.

3. In the a.m. of this date, the writer, per P.C. 1918, patrolled to the Hart farm, n.e. of Gladstone where BEAULIEU'S camp is located. The two boys, Wm. & Alfred were located and taken back to the Sandy Bay I.R. and handed over to Rev. Father Chagnon. At this time it was learned that Jimmie SUTHERLAND was seeing going across the ice on the lake, possibly making his way to Dog Creek I.R. The other brothers, Edwin was thought to have gone to Ebb & Flow I.R. in company with Alfred BEAULIEU.

4. At Westbourne enquiries made located George SUTHERLAND, father of Jimmie & Edwin. He is staying at Westbourne. His wife is dead and he has a mother-in-law, Mrs Mary SWAN, and a brother-in-law, Charlie Baptise (?) now living at Dog Creek reserve. He has seen nothing of his two boys and he is sure they will go to their grandmother or uncle & aunt at Dog Creek reserve. Should he hear anything further regarding them he will notify this office at once. He wishes them kept under observation.

5. Rev. Father Chagnon informed the writer, Cst. Harpell of St. Rose Det., is acquainted with Alfred ROULETTE, having returned him to Sandy Bay School about a year ago after he ran away. This boy will most likely be found with his father, Simon, at Ochre River.

6. Very meagre descriptions were furnished the writer but no doubt enquiries will reveal if they are in the dat. The descriptions follow,-

Alfred BEAULIEU, 13 yrs., wearing, cap, khaki coat, blue o'alls, gum rubbers.
Wm. SUTHERLAND, 14 yrs., inclined to be wild & crafty, wearing cap, khaki coat, blue o'alls, gum rubbers.
Edwin SUTHERLAND, 12 yrs., shy, wearing, cap, khaki coat, blue o'alls, gum rubbers.

7. Should the SUTHERLAND boys be located at Dog Creek reserve, they can be returned to Sandy Bay across the ice on Lake Manitoba, the chief at Dog Creek will act as escort. This according to Rev. Father Chagnon. Otherwise Mr Waite, Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie, will have to be communicated with.

Could the necessary enquiries be made at Dog Creek reserve by our Ashern Det., and at Ochre River by our St. Rose Det. please in an effort to locate these Indian boys. It is understood the parents of all these boys are anxious that they remain in the school at Sandy Bay.

P.T.O.

April 20th, 1940.

Alfred BEAULIEU et al., (Indians) Sandy Bay I.R. School,
Runaway Boys.

Kalwood Det., Cass.

With reference to the above I have to report
that during the last of this date the Cst. I/C Ste Rose
du Lac detachment communicated with this detachment stating
that Alfred Beauleau, one of the boys who had recently
run away from the Sandy Bay Indian School, was known to be
in the Ste Rose district and that the boy's father, Simon
Beauleau, had promised to locate him and return him to his
detachment at Ste Rose, so Cst. Harpell was requested elsewhere
on urgent police duties he requested that in the
event that this subject be located by his father that a
member of this detachment proceed to Ste Rose and take
charge of him.

In view of the above arrangement, Mrs. Harpell,
wife of the Cst. I/C Ste Rose du Lac detachment, telephoned
this detachment at 13:00 noon of the same date, stating
that this subject was being held at Ste Rose pending the
arrival of a patrol.

Acting on instructions of the H.O. I/C Beaupin
detachment an immediate patrol was made to Ste Rose du
Lac per Cst. SAD by the writer and Cst. Macdonald, where
on our arrival, Alfred Beauleau was handed over and
placed in custody. This boy was questioned regarding the
whereabouts of the Sutherland boys who had also run away
from the school and were reported to be in the vicinity.
Beauleau informed us that he had not seen J.Jay Sutherland
but that Edwin Sutherland and he had been together since
leaving the school and that Edwin had remained at George
Houle's house on the Bob and Floe Lake when he, Beauleau
had gone to Ste Rose du Lac.

Patrol was then continued to the Bob and Floe
Reserve where we located and questioned George Houle
regarding the whereabouts of Edwin Sutherland. Houle
informed us that Sutherland had left his place on the 16th.
inst., stating that he intended crossing Bob and Floe Lake
and going to the Dog Creek Indian Reserve where he had
friends.

We then contacted Cst. Harpell, who during the
course of enquiries had arrived at the Bob and Floe Reserve.
Cst. Harpell informed us that he had made enquiries
locally and already ascertained the information pertaining
to Sutherland and that on continued enquiries he failed to
obtain any information as to Sutherland having reached the
Dog Creek Reserve and further that owing to the precarious
condition of the ice on the lake it was feared that he may
have been drowned. This could not be substantiated as ice
conditions made it impossible to have a patrol search the
lake.

1. With reference to the above and further to the marginally noted P.C.R.'s, I have to report that whilst patrolling on the Lake Manitoba Indian Reserve, numerous enquiries were made concerning the above named boys.

2. I was informed that Jimmy and Edwin SUTHERLAND late of the Sandy Bay Indian Reserve were at present residing with their Grandfather Mrs. Francis SWAN and John BAPTISTE on the Lake Manitoba Indian Reserve (Dog Creek). Mr. J. MITCHELL, an instructor was then interviewed in connection with the SUTHERLAND boys and he informed me that he was aware of the fact that they had run away from Sandy Bay. Mr. MITCHELL also stated that he had phone Mr. J. WAITE, Indian Agent at Portage La Prairie and told him that the boys were living on the reserve. Mr. WAITE instructed MITCHELL to keep the boys there at present as he was undecided what to do with them.

3. Since the two SUTHERLAND boys arrived on the Reserve from across the lake on the ice, it is now impossible for them to return via the same route, as the lake is beginning to break up and it would be very dangerous to attempt crossing. It would be necessary to escort them to Winnipeg for further transportation to Sandy Bay Indian Reserve.

4. In view of the foregoing and unless otherwise instructed to the contrary, this file will be considered closed at this Detachment.

Ottawa, July 10, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In checking the June quarter return of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, it is noted that the name of Joyce Rouletta, No. 0205, is not shown although her name appeared on the March quarter return and no application has been received for her discharge. Please advise regarding this girl.

On the March quarter return from this school, Alice Mousseau, No. 0160, was stated to have been discharged on February 17, 1940. On the June quarter return, 91 days' grant is requested for this girl. In view of the information contained on the March return, the grant requested for her on the June return is not being allowed.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. J. Waite,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

I hasten to answer your valuable favor of the 23rd instant, I have found the error pointed out.

We sent for Joyce Roulette's admission during the month of December. Thus her name was shown on the report of December. Between December and March she was transferred to the Sanatorium. The error was done by copying from December report's.

Alice Mousseau is also an error of the sort since she was discharged on February 17th 1940.

To replace these two admissions we have 2 pupils, earning grant, in excess of the 75 allowed by the Department.

Yours very truly,

O. Chagnon. O.W.S.

DAUPHIN

MANITOBA

21-9-40

Michelle BONE & Jimmy MUNZER, Sandy Bay I.R., Man.

Runaway boys from the Sandy Bay Indian School.

15-9-40

With reference to the above I have to report that in the late P.M. of this date Trevor WILSON, a farmer residing on Miles North East of Glenella, Manitoba, telephoned this office to report that he had found two half breed children on the road a few minutes before. He stated that they would be about six and eight years old and he figured they were lost, although they would not or could not speak to him. He stated they were being looked after at his home for the night.

16-9-40

In the A.M. of this date patrol was made to the WILSON farm and I took these boys over. They gave me their names as above stated. Jimmy MUNZER appeared to be the only one of the two that could speak any English. He told me he was ten years old and his companion eleven. When asked where they came from, all three would tell me was Elphinstone. I thereupon brought them back to detachment and contacted the HQ 1/C, Shoal Lake detachment and informed him of the foregoing. He contacted the Indian agent at Birtle and later called me back stating that Michelle BONE belonged to the Limard Point Indian Reserve near Rossburn and was supposed to be at the Indian school at Sandy Bay. They had no record of Jimmy MUNZER.

In the P.M. of this date I patrolled with these boys to Sandy Bay Indian Reserve and handed them over to Father CHANNON, in charge of the Indian school at that point. He informed me that Jimmy MUNZER belonged to Bob & Flow Reserve and that these two boys had run away from the school the A.M. of the 14th instant and that it was the second time they had run away.

HANDED OVER,

RANGERS, Cst. Calverley.

The O.C., "D" Division,
Cst., Kelwood Detachment,
R.C.M.P., WINNIPEG, Man.

Ottawa, October 7, 1940.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 3rd instant, in which you seek information with respect to the pupil enrolment at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

The records here indicate that at some date during the fiscal year 1939-40 the enrolment at the Sandy Bay School was increased from 75 to 95. I should add that no provision has been made in the estimates of this year for an increase in the enrolment of pupils at any of our residential schools throughout the Dominion.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the September quarter return of the Sandy Bay Residential School it is noted that the name of Philomene Prince, No. 0204, is not shown although her name appeared on the June quarter return and no application has been received for her discharge. Please advise regarding this girl.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of October 15th, File 126-9-10, I have to advise that Philomene Prince, pupil No. 0204 of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School has T.B., and is to be ex-rayed again this Fall. If the report of her condition is satisfactory, her name will be included on the next quarterly return.

Your obedient servant,

"D" DAUPHIN STE ROSE DU LAC

MANITOBA MAY 17th, 1943

Frederick FISH, Treaty Indian Age 11 years.
Runaway boy from the Sandy Bay I.R.
Residential School.

( STE ROSE DU LAC DET. CASE )

12-5-43

1. I have to report that at 3:30 P.M. this date I received a telephone call from Rev. Father COMEAU of the Sandy Bay I.R. Residential School. Father COMEAU informed me that Frederick FISH of the Ebb and Flow I.R. had run away from the Sandy Bay I.R. School. Father COMEAU went on to say that they had tried to have the child returned to the school by the parents, but that up to the present time the child had not returned. Father COMEAU asked me to bring the child back to Sandy Bay I.R. School.

2. I proceeded from Ste Rose du Lac Man., at 3:30 P.M. this date per P.C.C.'s No. 1998 in company with Reg.No. 13706, 3/Cst.LTANASKI, S., to the Ebb and Flow I.R. District. We located Frederick FISH at the home of his parents on the I.R.. Roderick FISH, father of the child stated that his son Frederick had returned home on May 2nd, 1943 along with another child Robert FISH a brother of Roderick FISH. Robert FISH had been returned to Sandy Bay I.R. School by his father Joseph FISH. Roderick FISH claimed that his son Frederick had been sick and could not be taken back until he was better. I asked Roderick FISH why the boys ran away from the school. He stated that both boys complained about having to eat brown bread, and had to wear clothing with patches on. I examined the child's clothing, and although I saw one patch on the pants I personally consider the child was well dressed. The child also looked in good health, and one could see that the child had been well taken care of. No doubt the truth of the matter is that the children were home sick and as spring had arrived they wanted to go home. We then escorted the child to Ste Rose du Lac as the roads to Sandy Bay I.R. were impassable for a car. From Ste Rose du Lac we proceeded to McCready where we tried to proceed to the Reserve via Alonza. The roads in this area were also impassable due to recent rains. We then proceeded to the Sandy Bay I.R. via Neepawa.

13-5-43

3. We arrived at the Sandy Bay I.R. School at 3:30 A.M. this date, and handed over Frederick FISH to Rev. Father CHAGNON at the school. We remained at the school until 9:00 A.M. and then left for Ste Rose du Lac returning at 3:00 P.M. during the afternoon.

CONCLUDED: H.O.T.B.G.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from the R.C.M.P. with reference to Frederick Fish who truanted from the Sandy Bay Residential School. Apparently the police were asked on May 12 to locate this boy. In view of the instructions contained in circular letter of May 8, copy of which is enclosed, I should appreciate your advising what action was taken to secure the return of this boy without calling on the police. As you are now aware the services of the police will have to be paid for and from the information contained in the report that they have submitted it appears that the Indian Agent could have had him returned. Did you consult the Indian Agent before notifying the R.C.M.P.?

SANDY BAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

MARIUS. P. O. MAN.

May, 5th 1941.

MR. PHILIP PHELAN.
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:-

Re: Rodrick Fish.

Before calling a R. C. M. P. I have sent Rev. Father Comeau for bringing Frederic Fish to school. The father of the boy was not willing to let him go, so I have asked the service of a police, and it succeeded.

Your circular letter dated May 6th, has been received only May 16th, consequently when calling the police, May 12th, I had not received it.

I have not consulted the Indian Agent, it would have taken too much time, it was an urgent matter, the father of the boy had to be impressed and had to comply to his duty.

Yours sincerely,

O. Chagnon.
Principal.

26th August 1942

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing a declaration made by Francis Tanner and his wife of the Waywayseecappo Band, renouncing their adherence to the Roman Catholic Church, and desiring that their children be educated in the Birtle School. This declaration was given to me by Mr. Crump, the Presbyterian Missionary on the Reserve, who states that he feels sure that their desire to change is genuine. The Rev. Dr. Cameron, Secretary of the Home Mission Board of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, also interviewed the Tanners, and states that so far as he can judge, these people seem sincere in their desire to become Presbyterians.

Also I am enclosing a declaration which they made in August 1939, stating that they are both Roman Catholics, and desiring to have their children brought up in the Presbyterian faith.

I should have stated that only copies of these declarations are enclosed.

The Department approved of the discharge of these children from Birtle School in 1939, and later approved of their admission into Sandy Bay School, on account of the wishes of the parents in 1939.

On this Reserve there is great rivalry between the Presbyterian and Roman Catholic Churches, and the Indians are aware of it and taking advantage of it. There is another case of the same sort pending and no doubt others will crop up, if we allow all these changes. An Indian will have some complaint about the school, and will change his religious views, to have his children moved to another school. I do not know if that is the reason in the Tanner family or not, but I doubt if they were genuine in making both declarations.

There
There are at present eight children in this family, four of whom have attended Sandy Bay School. The others will soon be of school age, so that the decision of the Department regarding this matter will affect these children for many years yet.

I would suggest sending the children who are enrolled as pupils at Sandy Bay School back there to complete their education, and allowing the parents to send the younger children, who have not been to school, to Birtle, if they wish to do so, and make it plain to them that no further transfers will be allowed.

Please advise me of your decision regarding this matter as soon as possible, as the children will not return to school until then.

Yours truly,

A.G. Smith
Indian Agent

August 31, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Re: Children of Francis Tanner

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 26th instant and also a declaration made by Francis Tanner and his wife of the Waywayseecappo Band renouncing their adherence to the Roman Catholic Church and desiring that their children be educated at the Birtle Residential School.

It is scarcely necessary to state that everything possible should be done by our officials to discourage the transfer of pupils from one denominational school to another. These transfers have a tendency to interrupt their studies and must result in a great deal of perplexity and confusion to the pupils themselves. The recommendation made by you in the second last paragraph of your communication is perhaps the best arrangement we can make in view of all the circumstances. If you could assure us, however, that there is a day school within easy reach of these people the Department is of the opinion that these children should be discharged from the Sandy Bay School and encouraged to attend a day school. If no day school is available, however, your recommendation that the senior pupils be permitted to complete their education at Sandy Bay and that the younger children be enrolled in due course at Birtle is acceptable to the Department and approved.

Yours truly,

Mr. A.G. Smith,
Indian Agent,
Birtle, Man.

Ottawa,
January 25, 1943.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to our telephone conversation this morning, I discussed with Dr. Moore the possibility of having the nurse at the Sandy Bay School examine the children on entrance rather than sending them to the Medical Officer who resides some 65 miles from the school.

Dr. Moore stated that he could not see any objection to this procedure, on the understanding that the children examined by the nurse would be subsequently examined by the Doctor whenever he visited the school. Of course, you should point out to the nurse the importance of having all children physically fit before they enter the school, especially in the case of any contagious disease which might adversely affect the health of the other children. Dr. Moore mentioned that there is a Departmental nurse on the reserve and, if desired by the Principal of the Sandy Bay School, she could also be consulted.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Ave. East,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. J. Waite:

I am coming today for a very delicate question, which I am sure you'll consider with me, and have it placed to Ottawa, Department of Indian Affairs.

Lately, the Rev. Father Missionary, after many insistances made, since a year ago, on the part of the Archie Meech's family and himself to become Roman Catholics, has baptized them. Now, Mr. Archie Meech is wishing to have his four children be transferred to this Sandy Bay School... You'll find affidavids under same cover.

Mr. George Daniels Pte., insists to have his daughter, Patsy, to be transferred... as the reason of last year doesn't stand anymore, the Principal being changed, we should have our Department to decide.

Mr. John Daniels, having his son at the Portage School, insists also to him transferred to this School... being all of them Roman Catholics, they are wishing to have their children to be brought up so.

Application Forms have been signed by them, but first I would wait to have a reply from our Department before sending them in.

Would you kindly present to our Department Ottawa these cases. I'm sending a copy of this letter to Rev. Father J.O. Plourde, O.M.I., with copies of affidavids.

Many thanks for your great cooperation.

I remain always yours very truly,

Father J. Damire, O.M.I.
Principal.

OTTAWA.

I enclose herewith a letter received from the Reverend J. Lemire in regard to transfers from the United Church school at Portage to the Sandy Bay Residential school. The matter has been taken up with the Principal at Portage and he is definitely against any transfers of this nature.

Archie Meechas, 105 Long Plain was in the office April 9th this year and wished his son Gilbert admitted to Brandon. I spoke about the transfer of his other three boys who are at Portage and he wished them transferred to Brandon also. Transfer was approved by the Department 133-0-10 of June 1st 1943. It would appear that this Indian does not know his own mind and I would recommend that the transfer to Brandon be made.

George Daniels, 191 Long Plain is in the army. His daughter Patsey has been at Portage school since 1936. At the time of her admission she was a baby ½ years old, and was admitted because her father could not look after her. The school is in the child's home. A difficulty is experienced in having this child take holidays on the reserve. I feel it would be a hardship on Patsey to have her transferred.

Donald Daniels, 169 Long Plain has a son in school named Donald. He is 11 years of age and has been in school since 1937. He is now 12 years of age.

George Daniels is the son of John, and Mrs. Meechas is a daughter. John Daniels is the Medicine man of the reserve, beats the drum. He has had a grudge against Mr. Jones the previous Principal and appears to be carrying it along towards Mr. McNeill. I would not approve the transfer of any of these pupils but bring the matter to the attention of the Department.

Indian Agent
