My dear Mr. Phalen,

Enclosed please find affidavits from Archie Meeches, Private Daniels, and John Daniel requesting the transfer of their children from the Portage la Prairie School to Sandy Bay. The affidavits give the names and ages of all these children.

On August 5th last, Father Lemire wrote to Indian Agent Waite of the Portage la Prairie agency asking for the transfer of these children, but his request was refused. Father Lemire finds the ruling of Agent Waite all the more unreasonable, as he took four children from his school last September, and transferred them to the Birtle School against Father Lemire's protest. Father Lemire expected these children in September 1942, and as they were not forthcoming he wrote to the Agent to find out why they had not yet arrived. He was then informed that they were sent to the Birtle School at the request of the parents. No objection is taken to the ruling of the Agent in this case, if the wishes of the parents were fully known to him, because, after all, parents have the right to place their children in a school of their own choosing. But if Mr. Waite acceded to the wishes of the parents of the Tanner children, why did he refuse the request of Messrs. Meeches and Daniels?

If the case is as represented to me by Father Lemire, he certainly has the right to demand that the above children be transferred without delay from the Portage School to his own, as the will of the parents is made very clear in the accompanying affidavits.

Yours very truly,

Archie Meechais.
Indian Affairs Branch,

OTTAWA, Ontario.

I have your letter, file 126-9-10, dated October 7th, 1943, dealing with the transfer of certain pupils from the Portage School.

I tried to contact the parents last week but John Daniels and Archie Meschos are away hunting skunk and no one knew their whereabouts. Pte. G. Daniels, I understood, was at Shilo. I went there only to find he left on draft and his destination was not available.

The four Meschos children were transferred to Brandon this fall, with the Department's permission. Mr. Waite, however, told Archie at that time there was some question as to his religion, but he (Archie) insisted that the children go and signed the enclosed statement.

Patsy is Pte. G. Daniels' child. I understand she has spent all her school days at the Portage School and this is the only home she knows. The father, as pointed out above, is gone (perhaps Overseas) and I don't think a change should be made during his absence.

I was unable to see Donald Daniels but he brought his son to school and according to Mr. Waite made no complaint.

The Indians are all pretty well off the reserves yet, helping the white farmers and trapping, and it is, therefore, very difficult to contact them.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
for Manitoba.

Although this school has almost its allotted number of children there remain on the reserve about thirty-five pupils of school age. The Reverend Principal is anxious to take these children in but for some reason the parents will not consent. Re: Leechas and Daniels' Children,
Long Plain Reserve - Portage Agency.

I acknowledge your letter 126-9-10, dated November 29th, 1943, together with the enclosures. I spent several hours on Long Plain Reserve with these people on November 26th and would like to report as follows:

John Daniels, Senior, states he was baptized in a Protestant church many years ago, and was married by a Protestant minister. There were seven children all baptized by a Protestant minister and educated in the Birnie Indian School. Six have graduated and only Donald remains. Donald is now being educated in the Portage School about six years. John Daniels states that Father Comeau bothered him for years to turn his children Catholic, but he refused because his wife is Catholic, and he allowed Father Comeau to baptize his children when they were eight years old. He said it didn't make any difference to him whether he was bothered too much. Two years later he applied for religious papers for Donald and gave his religion as Catholic. This application is on file at Ottawa.

Donald stated he did not like Mr. Jones who was sent to Portage. He claims the children were poorly clothed and treated unpleasantly, and that was why he decided to transfer Donald to another school under Mr. McNeill conditions have entirely changed. Donald to remain at Portage. Both John and Donald stated they wanted Donald to remain and finish his education. They claim now to be perfectly satisfied with the Portage School.

Leechas claims he has no religion except the Catholic. His wife was one of the Daniels' girls who attended the Birnie School and was baptized and raised in the Catholic faith. The two girls graduates of the Birnie School went to London School, transferred to Portage School, and then back to the Birnie School. She allowed him to attend the Birnie School and shortly afterwards Donald came to Portage. Donald had the parents sign papers for Donald to attend Portage School and other papers received. Donald stated that some of the forms he forgotten and others he had been back in the Birnie School. Donald because the parents were unable to provide them and because Donald was unable to provide them as positive in the Birnie School.
Dear Father Plourde:

With further reference to my letter of the 2nd ultimo, regarding the Mechas and Daniels children, Inspector Hamilton was requested to investigate the matter thoroughly and, for your information, I quote from a report dated November 29:

"I acknowledge your letter 126-9-10, dated November 5th, together with the enclosures. I spent several hours on Long Plain Reserve with these people on November 26th and would report as follows:

"John Daniels Senior states he was baptized in a Protestant church many years ago; and was married by a Protestant preacher. There were seven children, all baptized by a Protestant minister and all educated in the Birtle Indian School. Six children have graduated and only Donald remains. Donald is thirteen and has been in the Portage School about six years. John Daniels stated that Father Comeau bothered him for years to turn Catholic as his wife is Catholic, and he allowed Father Comeau to baptize him about eight years ago. He said it didn't make any difference and he was bothered too much. Two years later he signed the application papers for Donald and gave as his religion "Protestant". This application is on file at Ottawa.

"John stated he did not like Mr. Jones who was principal at Portage. He claims the children were poorly clothed and school life unpleasant, and that was why he decided to transfer Donald. Now John states under Mr. McNeill conditions have entirely changed and he wants Donald to remain at Portage. Both John and his wife stated

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Ottawa, Ont.
that they wanted Donald to remain and finish his education at Portage. They claim now to be perfectly satisfied with the Portage School.

"Archie Meechas claims he has no religion except the Indian religion. His wife was one of the Daniels girls who graduated from the Birtle School and was baptized and raised in the Protestant faith. Meechas has two girls graduates of the Portage School and four children now at Brandon School, transferred from Portage. All the children were baptized by a Protestant minister when quite young. Mrs. Meechas stated that last June Father Lambert urged her to be a Catholic and she allowed him to baptize her. In July he baptized the children and shortly afterwards returned with the application forms and had the parents sign them. I am returning these forms and the other papers received. Both Mr. and Mrs. Meechas requested that these forms be forgotten and stated they would prefer to have the children back in the Portage School. They would prefer Portage to Brandon because the children would be nearer home where they could see them and because they liked the present Principal. Mrs. Meechas was as positive in this as was her husband.

"George Daniels is now overseas. Patsy has been at the Portage School from which school her dad graduated. Patsy was admitted when she was only two years and three months old and has been in the school for six years. Neither the father nor the grandparents have bothered much about this child until recently. Patsy cannot speak the Indian language. Before her father left he gave the enclosed statement to his father, John Daniels. John states this simply meant that during the summer Patsy was to spend her holidays in their care. They emphatically stated they did not wish to have Patsy transferred to any other school. Patsy is baptized a member of the United Church and her father signed the original application as of Protestant faith."

I am returning the various documents which you left with me.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief Training Division.

Dear Dr. Moore — Re: Madeleine Beaulieu — Sandy Bay, Manitoba — Indian Reserve.

I doubt you will recall that in the capacity of Superintendent of the Neepawa General Hospital I had occasion to write you several times about this child. A little over a year ago Madeleine was discharged from the hospital and sent to the Sandy Bay Indian School at Marinos, Manitoba — a clean, happy and well nourished youngster. You can perhaps imagine my surprise and natural indignation when I received this letter from her mother a short time ago.

I know that most Indian children suffer from "mechanized dandruff" when they are in groups and I know that all children wear each other's clothes. And, I do wonder if...
This school might be quietly investigated? This child especially requires to be well fed and properly looked after—she has a tubercular leg or rather she had—that being the reason for her long hospitalization and surgery. The Federal Government spent a great deal of money on this youngster. It would be a shame not to get a good result! No doubt the child's mother has had a "run in" over something with those in authority and thought it might help her. However, I think perhaps you could have it looked into—if you would be so kind. After all, the child is a ward of the government and if she requires help or protection she should get it. When she is through school there, I will give her what assistance I can—to get on with her education.

I have not written to the Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie because I felt perhaps the investigation should be done through some other channel and the child and her mother might get into a row over it all which would be too bad.

Thanking you in advance for your attention to this matter. Yours very truly—Gertrude A. Johnson
Ottawa,
November 1, 1944.

Dear Father de Bretagne:

On July 21, 1943, we wrote the former Principal, Reverend J. Lemire, O.M.I., regarding Madeline Beaulieu, who had been confined to the Neepawa General Hospital for a considerable period of time due to a tubercular knee. Our Medical Superintendent thought she could be discharged at that time and felt that it would be in her best interests to place her in a residential school. In a letter dated July 25 Father Lemire stated that he would be glad to receive her. I now enclose, for your information, a letter which has been forwarded to us. This letter was written by the girl's mother, who has remarried, and contains rather serious accusations regarding the care that the girl is receiving. It would be appreciated if you would let me have a report regarding the matters mentioned in the mother's letter and at the same time you should return the letter to me.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

Re 126-9-10 November 1-1944

I beg to inform you that all the statements of the said Mrs Willie Whiteford are rather erroneous and grossly exaggerated as you could judge from my investigation.

The girl, Madeline Beaulieu, came indeed from the Nepean Hospital and decidedly did not put any weight, not on account of lack of care, but by the fault of the girl herself who was so glad of being free from hospital restraint, that she was always on the move in spite of the vigilant watch of the Sisters. She was given special lunch of milk and beaten eggs taken upstairs to the classroom (that are situated here on the top-floor) by the Sister in charge of the Infirmary to avoid unnecessary strain on the sore leg of the sick girl etc...

Now, after Nurse W ilcox herself, who has lived long time in our very house and followed closely the treatment of the children's food is maybe not fancy but certainly better than in any home of the Reserve and very satisfactory to the say of that authority. This is what I am told.

The story of the clothes kept by the School authority is absolutely false. When the girl went for Holidays she took along a bulky suitcase of the said clothes after promise made by the Mother that they will come back after holidays what she did not do of course because she intends to keep these clothes for the other children she has at home. But the girl's intention is to use these things herself and the Sisters are helping her by enlarging those that are too small. The special ire of the Mother was specially excited when Rev. F. Lemire exacted a letter as proof of the intentions of the donator concerning the destination of the said clothes. The Mother's envy was concerning a kind of eiderdown quite nice and that she wanted on account of the birth she was expecting in her home. The girl was reluctant for giving it by fear of seeing it spoiled, she did not like to tell that herself to her own Mother and she was even at that time averse of receiving the visit of that woman at the parlor to avoid that discussion.

Now you can see from the above details the kind of accusations directed against the School. This of course would have been avoided if the recipient of the letter would have investigated herself from us or if she would have been acquainted with the groundless criticism that often comes from Indians when they are not given according to their boundless fancies;

As for the last accusation of being lousy, we have to say that we were not called to witness the veracity of that declaration. The children are always given a special care about that matter but the visit of "lousy" Indians accompanied often by a numerous progeny that should be in school to be "deloused" instead of being...
allowed to rove at large as they usually do in this Reserve, is very often a source of a new invasion of these vermin that seems to thrive so well on the degenerated specimen of our race.

We are, of course, ready at any time to have the visit of anybody specially the recipient of the letter written by that Mother who likes better her own interest than the good of her child.

The matter of lice should not shock you, but permit me to call your attention upon the fact that since the War and its restrictions we would appreciate receiving again some of that wonderful "Mercuric ointment", that I am said do so well on the children that are prone to be "lousy".

We thank you very much for your cooperation in that matter in interrogating us about that story.

We remain

Yours truly,

Rev. M.de Bretagne O.M.I
Principal.

Ph. Phelan
Chief Training division

I am asking you that when you coming to see Madeleine Beaulieu, you might just as well come as soon as you received my letter as they don't take care of her well she's lousy and thin too. The school is nice but they don't care for the children I was at school so I know it, but it's going at the school so I would like you if you could come sooner about her clothes what she had when she was in Nepawa she got lots of clothes and nice and good ones to when they had their vacation on June 26th they didn't let her bring her clothes home. They are stingy of them, it's the nuns and the priest. I went and asked them about her clothes and they didn't give them to me, and when they have party at school the other girls put them on, and this is what I don't like and one thing it would be different if they bought the clothes for her. This is what I don't like, when you come to see please take them all and bring them to me. I could keep them at home for her, and please don't write a letter ahead when you coming you will see her how she dressed when she came home on June she was so lousy, and this is not all I'll tell you more when you come. This is honest no lie or fibs.
I'm very sorry I put her at school here she was alright at the hospital so please don't write ahead when you coming they might dress her up clean she's not well fed etc.

write to Mrs Miller Whiteford

I was absent when your letter dated November 29th arrived, but a copy was sent to Mr. Waite. Today I received the following letter from Mr. Waite:

Dear Sirs:

I am a Treaty Indian belonging to Ebb and Flow Reserve, Manitoba. I have been sending my three children to Sandy Bay Residential School because I lived too far (5 miles) from our Ebb and Flow Reserve school for them to walk. Now I have horses and can drive those children to our own school. But I was told by the Agent that I would have to send them to Sandy Bay. Will you please tell me if I can keep my children at home and drive them to our own school each day. For two years now when holiday time came my children were not brought all the way home but were left two miles from home and had to walk. I am not satisfied with the way the children are treated at Sandy Bay and there is plenty of room at our own school if you will give me authority to send them there. Thank you.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Roderique Levasseur.
Ottawa, August 3rd, 1945.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.,

I enclose for your information a letter received from R. Lavasseur, with reference to his three children who are in the Sandy Bay Residential School.

You will note his reasons for wishing his children discharged. Personally, I am under the impression that he is simply applying for their discharge in order that he can secure the Family Allowance for them. If he resides five miles from the Ebb and Flow Day School, I doubt very much if he will drive the children to school every day. If they do not attend regularly it would mean the Family Allowance would be cut off with consequent trouble to yourself.

From the information contained in his letter I do not see any reason for granting the discharge of these children from the Sandy Bay School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

Re: The case of Madeleine Beaulieu -
Sandy Bay Indian Reserve, Manitoba.

I have just been notified that this child is in very poor condition. She left the Sandy Bay Indian School at Marinos in quite average condition and has spent the summer with her mother.

There is a great deal of correspondence on file with your department re. this child. She has a tuberculosis knee and considerable money has been spent on her care and treatment in the Neepawa General Hospital, Neepawa, Manitoba and in St. Boniface Hospital, St. Boniface, Manitoba under the

Care of Dr. A.P. MacKinnon. The request was received at the time of her discharge from the Neepawa General Hospital in 1943. She was enrolled in the Sandy Bay Indian School at Marinos, Manitoba in excellent condition in every way.

The inference is from the report that the practice of sending the children out with the parents in the summer does not work well in her case. She gets neither care nor enough food and as an old tuberculosis case she needs plenty of both if the money already spent on her is to be gained. I am afraid to say nothing of the child's life—present and future.

Can something be done to see that this child is kept at the school—not sent out with her parents—at any time since they cannot look after her—until she is of an age where I can give her some assistance without interference from her mother? Will you please see that something is done for this youngster? If she cannot remain at that particular school as a permanent Boarder could you have her transferred to some other school where she can be kept?

Thanking you in advance, I am,

Ottawa, 21st September, 1945.

Dear Father Lambert:

On July 21, 1943, we wrote the former Principal, Reverend J. Lemire, O.M.I., regarding Madeline Beaulieu who had been confined to the Neepawa General Hospital for a considerable period of time due to a tubercular knee. Our Medical Superintendent thought she could be discharged at that time and felt that it would be in her best interests to place her in a residential school. In a letter dated July 25, Father Lemire stated that he would be glad to receive her.

On November 1st, 1944, we wrote to Reverend Father de Bretagne, then Principal of the Sandy Bay School, and forwarded to him a letter which we had received. This letter contained complaints that the mother had made to Miss Gertrude Johnson, R.N.

Father de Bretagne replied to us in a letter dated November 7th and gave us a very complete explanation regarding the treatment that this girl was receiving at Sandy Bay School.

I am now in receipt of another letter from Miss Johnson and I enclose a copy of this for your information.

I would like to know if the girl spent her holidays with her parents this year and if so for what length of time.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. Jean Lambert, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sandy Bay Indian Residential School,
Marius, Manitoba.

Dear Father Lambert:

I am returning the September quarter return of the Sandy Bay Residential School. It is evident that in many cases you are not asking grant which could be allowed. For instance, pupil No. 197, S. Bone, is marked on the return "Home without reason" and no grant is requested for him. On the June quarter return grant was requested and allowed for the full quarter, and presumably this boy was in the school until June 30, 1945, and was allowed home on holidays but did not return upon the expiry of his leave. Consequently, in his case, you are entitled to 62 days' grant, namely, the holiday leave. What has been said regarding this boy applies to other pupils on the return. In this connection I would refer you to paragraph 6 of circular letter of December 28, 1944. It is quite evident, in preparing the September quarter return of the Sandy Bay School, that no attention has been paid to that letter.

I enclose another copy of this circular letter and suggest a careful study of it, because it was prepared to assist the Principals of Residential Schools to obtain the grant to which they are rightfully entitled.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J. Lambert, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sandy Bay Indian Residential School,
M a r i u s, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Reverend Father PLOURDE, Superintendent of the Oblate Indian Welfare and Training Commission, states in a letter which I have just received, that he has asked an increase in the pupilage of this school from 95 to 130.

If I write you today in this connection, it is simply to let you know that not only do I approve of the step taken by Father PLOURDE, but that I think it is essential for the welfare and training of the Indians of this Reserve. As you may know from the latest statistics, this Reserve has about 150 children of school age, ranging from 7 to 17 in age and of this number, only 42 are at school at the present time. This leaves over two-thirds growing in ignorance and without the benefits of the training received in a Residential School. I think this is unwarranted, in view of the fact that the school can accommodate between 50 to 60 additional pupils. There are no other school to which these children can be sent and due to the condition of the roads, the poverty of the Indians and the distances to travel, no day-school could supply the educational

(over)
needs of these children.

Under those circumstances I not only approve of the demand made by Father Plourde, but think it my duty to substantiate it in every respect.

Knowing Sandy Bay as you do, for having lived in Manitoba so many years, I am sure, Dear Sir, that you will grant our request and enable the Sandy Bay School to supply its large population, the services which, due to war conditions, it was unable to dispense to it.

I remain, dear Sir, yours very truly,

Reverend Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to send back your December Quarter Return for the following reasons.

The information given regarding the new pupils namely pupils No. 270 to 272 inclusive and No. 0268 to 0277 inclusive is not the same on the Quarterly Return and the I.A. All form. For instance, pupil No. 0268 is stated on the Quarterly Return to have entered the school on October 5th while on form I.A. 411 it is stated she entered the school on October 17th. There are similar discrepancies in the case of pupils Nos. 0272, 0273, 0274, 0275, 0276 and 0277.

On the Quarterly Return you show dates for the admission of new pupils subsequent to October 1st, yet in all cases you request 92 days grant. In the case of new pupils, grant is only allowed from the date on which they entered to the end of that particular quarter.

I am inclined to feel you have not read the circular letter of December 29th, 1944, nor reviewed the notes on the preparation of the Quarterly Return as they appear on the last page of the Return.

The heading on the Return "Date of Entrance to the School" means exactly what it says, in other words you should show under this heading the exact date on which the pupil entered the school. This heading does not refer to the date the application was received or the date on which the pupil was formally approved. Either of these dates might be considerably later than the date on which the pupil actually entered the school. It has always been our practice to allow grant from that date on the understanding that the Principal will only accept those whom they consider are eligible and if subsequent facts prove a pupil ineligible for admission it would be necessary to return the pupil but in the meantime the school would have been allowed grant for their maintenance.

I trust that you will make the necessary corrections in the Return to correspond with the above, as these Returns are very carefully scrutinized by the Auditor General and we simply must have them correct and the information appearing on the I.A. All form regarding admissions and discharges of pupils must be exactly the same as that appearing on the Quarterly Return.

To assist in your finances we are forwarding a part payment of $3,000.00 on the December quarter Earnings and the balance will be paid when you send back the Return completed in the proper manner.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Jean Lambert, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sandy Bay Indian Res. School,
Marius, Manitoba.

Philip Phelan,

Dear Father Lambert:

In the case of pupils Numbers 0278, 0279, 0280 and 0281, you show on the Return that "Date of Entrance to School" was February 27, and you consequently request 30 days' grant for each of them. However, in the margin you state that each of them was in the school for 90 days.

Dear Father Lambert:

I have a letter from Indian Agent Waite, in which he states that he has a request from you, that Miss MacCarthy, the School Nurse, be allowed to take home a number of children when they are leaving on their annual summer holidays.

This is a new request and while I have no great objection to it, I cannot see why the school management cannot handle the matter. It would give yourself or any other member of the staff a chance to meet the parents and possibly secure the promise of new pupils for the coming academic year.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, August 23, 1946.

Rev. Jean Lambert, G.M.I. Principal, Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, Marius, Manitoba.

With reference to the June Quarter Return of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, I wish to inform you that formal approval for the admission of Eileen Catsgas was sent to Indian Agent J.L. Bryant on 27 February, 1940. In view of the above we made the necessary adjustment on the return by allowing this pupil ninety-one days grant and trust you will allot her a school number in the September Return.

To simplify the compilation of future returns, I suggest that where pupils are absent from school for a full quarter either through hospitalization, parents keeping the pupil home, etc., that the Department be requested to approve their discharge so that their names may be removed from the return. This would apply to pupil No. 265 Walter McLean who has been attending a school in Winnipeg for the last four quarters. Of course, the discharge of any pupil will only be requested after it has been determined that the child is not expected to return to school for some time. In the event that a child is discharged and at a later date returns to the school, the re-admission of the pupil should be requested from the Department and a notation made in the remarks column of the return opposite the child's name, giving the date of re-admission.
Care should be taken to allot the pupil the same number as the child had prior to discharge.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, 1 October 1946.

Mr. A.G. Smith, Indian Agent,
BIRTLE, Manitoba.

We are in receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo with reference to the Bone children. Our records show that five of these children were regularly admitted to the Sandy Bay Residential School and attended that school until June 30, 1945. We have no record of Isabelle Violet Bone being enrolled at Sandy Bay. Cathrine Bone is shown on the June quarter return of the Sandy Bay School as pupil No. 9269.

The Principal of the Birtle Residential school had no right to accept the five children who had been attending the Sandy Bay School. If there was a bona fide change of religion on the part of the parents, this matter should have been brought to our attention and our decision given before accepting them at Birtle.

You should inform the Principal that these children should be returned to the Sandy Bay School from which they have not been discharged. They were simply allowed home for the summer holidays on the distinct understanding that they would return to the school upon the expiry of their leave.

I feel certain that the Principal of the Birtle Residential School will promptly carry out the instructions contained in this letter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, 1 October 1946.

Dear Father Lambert:

We have received your telegram of the 26th ultimo with reference to the Bone children. We have also received a lengthy report from Indian Agent Smith.

Instructions are being sent to Mr. Smith to inform the Principal of the Birtle School that the five Bone children enrolled in your school and in attendance at your school on June 30th, should be returned to the Sandy Bay School.

We are advised that some of the Indians of Riding Mountain Reserve have a grievance against Sandy Bay School. We are informed that last January Marie Bone who was a pupil at Sandy Bay School, and is the daughter of Angus Bone, was sent to hospital in Portage la Prairie. In March, she was transferred to Dynever Hospital and the parents claim that they were not advised of the girl being sent to Portage la Prairie or her transfer to Dynever until she had reached the latter hospital and the doctor in charge advised Indian Agent Smith.

I would like your comments on the above statement. I think you will agree with me that it is most important for a Principal of a Residential School to notify the parents immediately any child is so seriously ill that it is found necessary to send her to hospital. Such information of course should also be given to the parents in the case of serious illness of a pupil who is being treated at the school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J. Lambert, O.M.I.,
Sandy Bay Indian Residential School,

Dear Mr Phelan,

Your last letter of October first requesting our comment concerning the case of Marie Bone, has been received. At the time she was taken to Portage la Prairie hospital, Marie's condition was not thought so serious as to need a long stay in the hospital. In fact we did not think she would return shortly to school. However a letter was sent to her parents informing them that she was in Portage hospital. It appears that this letter was not received by Marie's Parents, but I am certain that I did send them a letter informing them that Marie was in Portage hospital. I was informed of Marie's transfer to Dynevor hospital by Doctor Campbell supervisor of this hospital after she had arrived there. I visited Marie at Dynevor hospital and she complained that she had received no letter from her parents. I gathered from this that they likewise had not been advised of her transfer. I also told me that she had written her parents but had received no answer to her letters. Returning to my school, I wrote to George Bone Marie's older brother, an ex-pupil of this school, whom I knew could read and write, and I told him of his sisters condition. I asked him to make sure that his parents be told of Marie's conditions. I also asked him to write to his sister. However I do not know if George received my letter or whether he told his parents.

During the summer holidays I was absent from the school to attend a summer course in Quebec. Before leaving however I asked Doctor Campbell to keep my assistant at Sandy Bay and Indian Agent Smith informed of Marie's condition, and again from Quebec I wrote to Doctor Campbell asking the same. Two letters were received in reply to my request. Indications on these letters led my assistant to believe that the same information was being sent to Mr Smith so no further steps were taken.

Hoping that these details furnish the information you need on this matter.

Yours truly,

Fr. Jean Lambert, C.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Mr Waite,

Rodrigue Fish and Rodrigue Manigens, both of Ebb & Flow are anxious to have their children transferred to the day school at Ebb & Flow. I have no objections to the transfer, if you deem it wise. I leave the matter to your judgment. However, may I submit a few observations which may assist you in judging the case: The teacher at the Ebb & Flow school told me recently that the school room cannot accommodate any more pupils, it is full as it is now with the present pupils in attendance.

Jim Manigens 214, Rodrigue Manigens's boy, lives right near the school as you know, and could easily attend daily. Jim is now quite a big boy, and, as we have found out at this school may give the teacher some trouble.

As for the two little Fish (Levasseur girls; Hilda 0231 & Elsie 0260), they live some five miles from school and are quite delicate as to health. While they were at School here we gave them special care; although their father may have contrary observations concerning this, especially on account of his son Paul 203 who is still in St Vital. I found that the little girls have lost considerable weight during the holidays and personally I doubt very much that they be able to attend the day school regularly. It would perhaps be wiser for them to return to Sandy Bay, because of the distance from the day school and the girls' state of health, but as I have already stated, I wish to leave the matter with you. Their father seems to have an abiding fear, because of his son's long stay in St-Vital, and no length of reasoning will dispel this, and for this reason I prefer to leave Rodrigue entirely free.

The children present at Sandy Bay School now, have in the month since their arrival, gained from one to thirteen pounds.
Instruction were given to Mr Smith and Birtle principal to have the Bone children of Elphinstone returned to this school. This information was received in a letter from Mr Philip Phelan, and we transmit it to you.

Yours truly,

Father Jean Lambert, OMI.

I beg to refer you to your letter No.106-1-10 (WT), of 5th inst., regarding the Bone children from the Riding Mountain Reserve at Elphinstone, who were admitted to Birtle School without authority, while still enrolled as pupils at the Sandy Bay School. The children are now at home.

I have now interviewed the parties concerned and have obtained all the information I could about their religious belief.

First I will deal with the family of Jonathan Bone.

Jonathan was baptized in the Presbyterian faith, and his parents were Presbyterians. His wife, Marie, was baptized in the Roman Catholic Church. Jonathan never attended school, but his wife was a pupil at Pine Creek School. They were married by a Presbyterian minister. They have four children living, Michael, Ronald, Jean and Josephine, and as babies they were all baptized as Roman Catholics. The parents do not know the baptismal dates, but they are likely on record at the Sandy Bay School. Ronald, Jean and Josephine were all baptized by the Presbyterian minister at Elphinstone on September 5th of this year.

Regarding the family of Angus Bone. Angus was baptized as a Presbyterian, as his parents belonged to that faith. He attended Regina Indian School. His wife, Rose, was baptized Roman Catholic. They were married by a...
... married by a Roman Catholic Priest. The children of this marriage were baptized when babies as Roman Catholics. Catherine was baptized by the Presbyterian minister in Elphinstone on September 5th, this year.

Thomas Bone was baptized Presbyterian and his parents were Presbyterians. He attended Birtle School. His wife, Susette, was baptized Roman Catholic, and attended the white school in Elphinstone as she is a halfbreed. They were married by a Presbyterian minister and later on by a Roman Catholic Priest. The children by this marriage were all baptized Roman Catholics as babies, and Marrillia and Isobel were baptized by the Presbyterian minister on September 5th, 1946. Marrillia was also baptized by a Presbyterian minister on June 16th, 1935.

I have no copy on file of the application for admission to Sandy Bay School for Ronald Bone.

The applications for admission to Sandy Bay School for Catherine Bone is dated September 30th, 1945; it is signed by the father, Angus Bone, and the religion given was Roman Catholic.

The Principal of the Birtle Indian School does not know these families, and the Missionary who was there when the children were admitted to Sandy Bay School, is now gone, so I cannot say why the Presbyterians did not complain at that time.

I have known these families for eleven years and have always considered them to be recognized Roman Catholics.

As there is a school at Marius for all halfbreed children 2½ miles away, also the mother Mrs. Ethel Chanin has intimated that she wished her children to attend the Marius school, I have requested the Principal Father Lambert to let the children return to their mother so that they may attend that Day School.

Kindly advise if this is the correct procedure to follow.
